												In Transistor, you play as the silent starlet and singer Red, traversing the eerily empty yet colourful city of Cloudbank. The city is slowly being overtaken by a mysterious force known only as the Process, and Cloudbank's leaders have something to do with it. Desperate to put a stop to whatever's happening, Red goes out to hunt -- but not alone. She carries a sword-like contraption with her known as the Transistor, whose dulcet and heartfelt tones guide her (and you) through a decaying world...Pros+ Beautiful, mesmerizing art & visuals+ The Transistor's narration of the game+ The dreamy, cyber-like soundtrack+ Combining functions for cool attack abilities+ The overall emotional impactCons- Combat can get a bit repetitive- The main story could have been longer & more in-depth- Some story elements are left deliberately vagueThis one of the most beautiful & artful games I've ever played! The overall cyberpunkish atmosphere, the gorgeous artwork, the hauntingly loving voice of the Transistor... The game has story elements that are quite familiar in the sci-fi sphere, but its execution is just so good. I fell in love with Red, the Transistor, and their world in a little over five hours already, and bawled my eyes out at certain points during the story. The emotional pacing, aided by the superb soundtrack, was fantastic. The upsides of this game far outweigh any downsides -- which for me personally, were the slightly repetitive combat (mostly due to lots of the same enemy types, I think) and the fact that the first run-through of the story was not longer, meatier & more in-depth.Like sci-fi, strategical planning in combat (on pause), and a deeply emotional story? Then this one's for you. This game is a perfect little jewel, with my compliments to Logan Cunningham's excellent voice acting as the Transistor.

												Game Name: TransistorOriginal Release: 2014Personal Rating: AEstimated Playtime:18 HoursMultiplayer/Coop?: NonePlayed on: Steam ControllerTransistor is an indie game created from the same makers of Bastion. It is a unique rpg that has an interesting balance between turn-based gameplay and real time gameplay.Controls: When I played this, I used the Steam Controller. It wasn’t hard to use at all, and it seemed rather natural to use a controller with the game. Joystick seemed prime for the movement option, and the four buttons on the face of the controller worked really well with the four skills that you have to use in-game.Graphics: This isn’t a Crysis level of graphics. Coming straight out of an indie studio, it seems unique and more like art. Cut-scenes mix in well with the 2.5D gameplay, and it’s easy to figure out what is happening as time goes on.Music: Much like Bastion, Supergiant Games (the creators) release excellent soundtracks and this is no exception. Between the songs that you unlock and Red’s (the Main Character) humming, you find yourself playing the game for the music instead of the gameplay.Overall: Transistor has a unique and potent combination of great music, easy controls and compelling gameplay, all within a fun game with an interesting plot. No super strategy is needed as you will eventually figure out the game throughout time. I would recommend it at any price, but it does drop down during the sales.

er 6, 2015
												A deeply inspired game. Transistor not only has a nice aesthetic, but a handful of well implemented and creative gameplay mechanics. It is a healthy marriage of arcade power-ups and tactics, where player experimentation is key. For games that promise both live and turn based action, the player is usually given the choice between either - in Transistor you will want to master both forms of gameplay if you wish to gain the edge.The most intriguing part of the game is the power-up system. Throughout the game the player collects a series of "functions". These functions can be used as new attacks - choosing up to a total of four moves. Each function has a unique effect, letting the player choose from sneak attacks, long range strikes, clustering explosions, summoning minions, and more, or any combination of these. But the functions aren't limited to simple attacks. In addition to the four move slots, the player also has four passive slots to install their functions, and each move has two upgrade slots. The upgrades are really something special, allowing the player to improve and expand on or even change completely the nature of a move. As the player collects more of these functions, playstyles can become more and more diverse. The number of possibilities are staggering.The gameplay itself is challenging enough that certain combinations may be found ineffective or require careful planning and skill to use. This is what makes the game whole as an interactive experience. The player has to strategize, adapt, evaluate, refine, rearrange. You can't just brute force your way through (though certain combinations do give a whole new meaning to "brute force"). You can't just grind to max stats and max gear.If you like games that emphasize tactics and positioning, and enjoy making lots of experimental play styles. THIS is the game for YOU. If you don't, well, do me a favor, play it anyway.

content:
y 18, 2015
												Alright, first and foremost let me point out that I have recommended this game, which will contrast with what will sound like a negative review. If it comes off that way it's because I felt like Transistor could have been so much more, but standing next to Bastion it's withering in the shade. Overall it was an enjoyable experience, but at the end of the day I'm glad I got it on sale or I might have been very disappointed.Let's start with the things I enjoyed about the game. The thing that jumps out first is that there's a lot of love behind this game. You can tell that Supergiant wanted to really connect with their audience by creating an immersive world and characters that you can sympathize with. The real-time/active-time combat tries new things while staying grounded in somewhat familiar territory for most strategy/rpg fans, and being able to 'socket' abilities into other abilities makes for some interesting emergent play-styles.Now for the things I didn't find very enjoyable, or thought could have been done better:First- about that immersive environment Supergiant wanted to create in Transistor. Personally, I felt like that was a total whiff. They should have called this game Esoterica, because it's filled with fluff that is never explained. It's like picking up a sci-fi book you've never read before and know nothing about- picking a random page in the middle, and reading for four hours. By the end you know more than you did at the beginning, but you're still lost for the most part.. you're missing fundamental information to make sense of the story.As far as the characters go, I wanted to feel connected to them- I read every little bio and sought out every OVA station to learn more about the world and its inhabitants- but it feels hollow. Like they're trying too hard to live up to Bastion, which achieved greatness in both gameplay and storytelling almost effortlessly.I found the "narrator" in this game to be completely obnoxious. In Bastion the narrator added a lot of flavor and backstory to the world, since as a third party witness to the events that were going down, he could provide information that the player needed to feel connected to the things that were happening around them. In Transistor, he just monologues.. it's like going on a road trip with somebody who can't make meaningful conversation and doesn't like the sound of silence so they read every billboard you see. Eventually you would rather swerve into oncoming traffic than hear that there's a Cracker Barrel in 2.7 miles.The game itself is reasonably fun, if a bit repetitive (which is kind of a strike against it in its own right... how can a game with so much personality be repetitive after only 3 hours?). The ability socketing system is a very interesting spin on the whole 'play how you want RPG' genre. It's easily exploitable for those who want an easier time with things- but for players looking for a challenge can apply handicaps that award you with additional experience at the cost of a harder game. I would have liked to see a bit more variety here, but it's clear that they were designing a 4 hour game and not a 20 hour game.I ran into a LOT of bugs, which was disappointing considering how late to the Transistor party I am. Supergiant has had ample time to fine tune the experience- but I was running into issues where all of the AI models were missing (you could mouse over them and get tooltips, but the models were missing). A few times during combat I was teleported outside of the "ring" and couldn't get back in, so I was locked into a combat state and couldn't end the fight- so I had to force-close and restart. And just pathing issues in general.. plenty of times I'd click on a point to run to, but Red would choose the most bizarre path to get to an unobstructed position. This happened frequently during combat turns, where the incorrect path taken would basically ruin all of the proceeding commands (attacks firing into thin air, etc). It wasn't so frequent that it was game-breaking, but it happened enough to merit mentioning.And if you don't want any spoilers, this is probably a good spot to stop reading because I need to vent about something that happens at the very end of the game.Still here? Okay. So one of the things I'd read about this game was that it had a "strong female lead" and that supergiant was doing a great service to female gamers with Transistor. Now, full disclosure- I'm a dude, so it's entirely possible that I don't get it. I fully recognize that I may in fact lack the extra "X" chromosome to understand what girl gamers are looking for in a game with a female lead. However, at the end of the game when Red chooses to off herself to be with this guy we (the player) know nothing about had my eyes rolling into the back of my head. I felt like it was a cheap romantic plug at the end of what could have been a somewhat interesting (albiet confusing) story. Here she is with the 'brush' that could remake the world- she could un♥♥♥♥ everything that the calimari or whoever destroyed. But instead she rebuilds a plaza, then sits down next to the narrator's body and stabs herself with the big blue sword. Poetic I guess? Maybe we need more context. Maybe the world isn't worth saving if they can't be together, but Supergiant gave us NOTHING on this guy. Not a name, not a backstory.. nothing. His bio card is "Unknown" with zero information. Anyway.. It's worth playing. It has its problems, but it did not live up to my expectations at all.

content:
, 2014
												From the creative geniuses at Supergiant Games comes Transistor, a birds-eye sci-fi RPG with a strategic twist in its gameplay functions that creates a gaming experience that is both refreshing and unique in today's video game market. The first thing the player will notice in the game is the art-style and narrative reminiscent of Bastion; stylized environments, characters and enemies that can be instantly recognized and a story that is unveiled in little pieces through the smooth tones of the games narrator, who is actually the talking sword you're using throughout the game. Which creates a much more atmospheric effect than Bastion as the narrator is sharing in your experience instead of outlining what happens as you play. Transistor's story is difficult to percieve at the beginning, but as the player progresses and pays attention to the narrative and ques from the world one can piece it together over time. For the gameplay, Transistor is similar to Bastion in the birds-eye view controls and sporadic groups of enemies that have different strengths and weaknesses that you must approach in a careful manner or else you risk exposing yourself to more damage than needed. However, that is where the similarities between the two games end. Transistor uses a "Turn()" function that allows the player to pause combat in order to plan out their movements and attacks, then executing them in rapid succession, Turn() is mildly similar to the VATS system in Fallout 3, but much more unique and reactive than simply "clik on whurr u wanna shewt and hope u dunt miss". Turn() is useful for allowing yourself to punch a hole through enemy defences or to allow yourself some breathing room. However the drawback that must be taken into consideration is the short cooldown after Turn() ends, during which you are completely vulnerable as you cannot attack until the cooldown duration ends. Turn() gives players endless possibilities when combined with the notable selection of specific attacks that you are given access to, which can range from a simple energy blast to a quick dash, and even summoning a friendly unit to help you in combat (which can also be controlled during Turn()). One thing that makes the combat fast-paced and reactive are the "cells" dropped by all enemies when killed. Cells have a roughly 10 second cooldown timer when dropped, and if aren't picked up before the duration ends the enemy you just killed will respawn with full health, which in my opinion makes the combat much more dynamic and fast paced. Another point of interest in the combat system is the power selection and upgrade system. The player gathers a good selection of abilities throughout the game, but you can only equip four at a time. Never fear, because you can take the other abilities you gathered and use them to upgrade the abilities you currently have equipped to create powerful combinations. The only thing keeping you from upgrading yourself to over-powered proportions and keeping the gameplay balanced is the memory, which will require consideration while upgrading.Finally, instead of chugging down health regenerating items in combat like in Bastion, the player instead needs to be absolutely mindful of their current health. When your health is depleted you will automatically enter an "Emergency Turn()" that gives you the chance to eliminate the immediate threat. But once you execute the Turn() you still only have one hitpoint left, and if you get hit again during the cooldown you will return to full health but one of your abilites will be "overloaded" and cannot be used until you reach an "access point" (which not only act as save points but also are the only places where you can equip and upgrade your abilities). Esentially your abilities act as your lives, and the more you "die" at a certain area, the more difficult that area will become.To summarize, Transistor is in my opinion much more fun than Bastion and a game I thoroughly enjoy playing. I honestly recommend Transistor to all who are reading this review.

												Transistor is an art-aesthetic game made by the same people behind Bastion, which will give you a good idea of what to expect from the game from a graphical perspective so I won’t waste time on that (except to say that it’s really pretty). As the story goes, you play a rogue vocalist on a quest to find out the meaning behind the mysterious events happening around her. The most important of which involving the accidental death of one of her biggest fans by a sword called the Transistor. You might think the gameplay is somewhat similar to Bastion and if you were to ignore the Turn() aspect, you would probably be right. However, this is where the game distances itself: at any point during combat, you can stop time and plan your next few moves, in a sequence, to be executed when you press the end turn button. This allows for some significant advantages over certain hardy foes that would normally steamroll you in real-time. Additionally, each of the processes you pick up can be slotted in one of three roes: active (for active-weapon use), upgrade (boosts active weapon), or passive (various passive benefits). This allows for a wide variety of process assignments that really lets you find your own personal combat style. If for some reason, you find the game to be too easy, you can add ‘limiters’ you have earned at any save point to spice things up in exchange for extra experience.I found the narrator to be a bit sycophantic, almost to the point where I expected him to wear a fedora and use phrases like “m’lady” while rambling about what it is to be “a gentleman” (especially certain parts of the game where he resembled a drunk version of himself with embarrassingly low levels of restraint). Despite all the cringe, the game is pretty fun and a good challenge if you turn on all the limiters and there are some challenge sections that may warrant a replay if you so desire.

												Alright. I played Bastion and I didn't care too much for it, and Transistor honestly just feels like Bastion 2 rather than its own game, but as far as sequels go, Transistor is a pretty good  sequel. It's a game that builds on everything its predecessor established with high polish. The gameplay is fun (moreso than Bastion for me because being able to stop and figure things out in the middle of some clusterf*cks is really all I wanted so that Bastion wasn't so frustrating to me), the art is beautiful (and I love this 2D/isometric pastoral handpainted fantasy that Supergiant has because it ages really well--see Legend of Mana), the music and voice acting are great (of course), the plot is um. Well it's okay. There's a lot of unanswered questions. And I wish it didn't all feel so familiar.I do think the weakest ideas of the game are where it obviously copies right from Bastion. Silent protagonist lead on by a snarky narrator. Little squiggly comma monsters that run around a lot and annoy you. Giant monster that attacks the screen randomly. Skill challenges for bonus powerups. The antagonists never meant for this apocalypse to happen.There's a part of me that wishes that what the game leads you to believe at the start (that you had just murdered someone with your talking sword and were now on the lam) is the thread the game ran with. Still. It's not everything I could hope a game like this to be, but I can't deny that this is a good one and that it kept me going to the end, I even seem to have taken a lot longer than most people, just because I liked chewing the scenery and reading the lore. And I like that there's queer characters too. That's like a bonus, but I try to give devs props for it whenever they do it and it doesn't suck.

												Let me start of by saying that what I write below is from the eyes of a person who has recently finished Transistor. At the beginning I knew this game was going to be good. The narrative pulled me along - and the world never lost it's curious nature. I found myself wanting to know what was next every moment I played. Something unique about transistor personally, for me. I haven't seen many games that pulled me a long the way it had. From an Artists perspective - may I just say this game is gorgeous. It's truly beautiful. I tried to savor every single location because of it. The immense use of color and vibrancy in some areas is literally awe inspiring. The designers and Artists who put their time into this game must have really enjoyed the whole process - because I can't fathom anything of this quality being made without considerable love and devotion to it. Gameplaywise? This game was challenging and fun. The way combat worked was unique to itself - and I enjoyed how much customization your abilities had. It's honestly impressive and fun to sit there figuring out how to build a character. I found myself drawn to a combination of summoning my pet luna and using her in conjunction with other control abilities. But there were so many different ways to go about this. The soundtrack, well.. how else can I put it? I'd have bought this if it were just /music/ it is so wonderful. But the narrative it flows along with can't be put to the side, either. The narrative the game follows gives quite a few on the songs an amazing meaning to the lyrics and themes - I enjoyed listening to each song and seeing how it told things the story hadn't quite covered. The story - my god the story. I'm not the toughest guy in the world, but I sure as hell don't cry over nothing. Without revealing too much, let me tell you the person who made this game's story was a genius. It's so beautiful on so many levels. I pride myself on the ability to take something away from a game's meaning and message - and this is a game that has a beautiful message at it's heart. If I had to say one thing about the ending, I would say it was exactly what I wanted - but not what I had expected whatsoever. You are always on your toes during the whole experience - you never quite see where it's going - and that's the most amazing thing I've ever experienced in a game of 2014. I reccomend this to all of my friends - and pretty much the whole gaming community. This is something you don't want to miss. It's truly something that won't be forgotten. 10/10

content:
4, 2014
												Transistor is a rather unique game, coming from the developers of Bastion, Supergiant Games. While some may have been expecting a story and gameplay similar to Bastion, it is fortunate that Supergiant Games did not down that route, and it is important to remember the following: Transistor is not Bastion, and Bastion is not Trasistor. That doesn't mean they don't have a few things that are alike, but they are very different games.Much like Bastion, much of the 'narration' of the game, if in this case it can be called that - is once again voiced by Logan Cunningham, who voiced the narrator of Bastion. Here, though, the voice is much more laid-back and relaxed rather than the rough voice he used before. It works, and helps distinguish his 'character' from being yet another narrator. You'll be hearing him a lot.The gameplay is quite solid, although, much like Bastion, not too difficult, for some not being difficult enough. To remedy that, there are the Limiters - which act much like Bastion's Idols - which make the game harder. The way you fight in Transistor will rely on you using the functions you have available, and the best thing about them is that they can 'upgraded' with other functions to change their effects slightly or fit into a 'passive' slot that passively affects things. For example, the first function you get, Crash(), does 50 damage and very temporarily stuns enemies. In another function's upgrade slot, it will make that other function temporarily stun the enemy. In a passive slot, it will reduce damage by 25% percent. There are 16 different functions in total, and that allows for a lot of different combinations . This allows you to use whatever functions fit your playstyle. For example, there's one that 'masks' you, making you effectively invisible to opponents, and another that temporarily switches their allegiance from opposing you to serving you. All of these functions can be used inside and outside Turn(), which is a fairly important mechanic: it stops time, and allows you to plan your moves, then perform them in a matter of seconds, but has a cooldown that spans several seconds, in which you can move - but can't use any functions. This helps when dealing with large amounts of opponents, or when you want to backstab them and they just won't stop moving. This also leads to situations where using Turn() wouldn't be necessary or very hard, due to the nature of some opponents - sometimes you will have to wait for the right time to use it, or decide whether to use it at all.In terms of music, it fits the game's world, and is very good. Obviously, that's no surprise, this being a Supergiant game after all. But it's the songs that have lyrics that stand out. In Bastion, there were only a few, about two or three. In Transistor, there are five. What's even better here, is that you can 'earn' the music to listen to them in what is basically the closest thing the game has to a hub by completing the game's challenges. Story-wise, the game doesn't give much exposition. Most of the story can be gathered by inferring from what the game shows and tells you through the 'narration', as well as the function files. This is probably where the game falls short for some, as some things are not immediately obvious.

content:
1, 2014
												This won't be very in-depth, and will only cover the basic aspects of the game. Click here for my full review.[www.thatvideogameblog.com]Transistor is easily my game of the year, and one of my favourite RPGs of all time. Over time I've looked back at the experience and I've come to the conclusion that, of all the games I've played in the past fifteen years or so, Transistor may just be the best out of all them. I ended up clocking in at around thirteen hours, but that includes the time in which it was alt tabbed to write my review. In created few hours, I played one of the most complete, engaging, immersive and beautiful games ever made. Without a shadow of a doubt, Transistor is a masterpiece.Mechanically, it plays out like an isometric RPG in the vein of Fallout, but with real-time elements and less skills to upgrade. The end result is a very smooth combat experience that still has a heavy emphasis on strategy without ever being overbearing or overcomplicated. Players use the Turn system to pause the game, queue up a series of attacks, and execute them. Once this is done, they will have to wait a short while before pausing the game, forcing them to play in real time, which more often than not means running for cover and re-positioning yourself as your enemies go on the offensive.Transistor makes up for its short length with mechanical depth. Each skill or "Function" can be used in one of three ways. First, they can be used as an active skill to defeat enemies in combat. Second, they can be used as upgrades to the aforementioned active skills. Finally, they can be used in a passive slot, with each granting you a unique ability. This system allows for a wide variety of distinct playstyles, which adds immense replayibility and variety to an already hugely enjoyable action roleplaying experience.As the icing on the cake, each Function corresponds to a person in the city of Cloudbank, the setting of the game. Using your skills in a variety of ways unlocks lore titbits that detail the backstory and fates of the world's denizens, allowing you to piece most of the story together yourself. Not only does this encourage players to experiment with as many different loadouts as they can, it also gives players a simple way to slowly uncover the game's lore without feeling as though the narrative is being crammed down their throat. In fact, much of Transistor's narrative is told this way.Much like BioShock, Transistor features a utopian city that has seen much better days, the backstory for which is slowly revealed through dialogue and narration sprinkled throughout the campaign. The story is always subtle and never ham-fisted. Most of the plot is delivered by the Transistor itself - voiced by the brilliant Logan Cunningham - the talking sword you'll be using to cut a swath through the Process, the primary antagonistic force you'll be fighting.Fighting the Process is as hard as you want it be. It never feels like it's being padded out unnecessarily, and offers additional challenge in the form of "limits". Limits add rules to the game such as enemies dealing more damage and having to be hit once before collecting their cells which, if not collected, will respawn the enemy. Brilliantly, using these will also reveal additional lore and grant the player extra experience points, which can be used to unlock new skills and upgrades. Losing all of your health doesn't mean dying either. If your HP hits zero, your most expensive skill will become overloaded and unavailable to you until you visit two more access points - the terminals at which the player can change their loadout. This is an elegant solution that keeps the action flowing, whilst still discouraging players from screwing up, and pushing them to try different tactics if what they're currently doing isn't working without constantly taking them out of the experience.All of this, and I haven't even mentioned how beautiful the game looks. It's beautiful. Seriously, it's Jen Zee. You can see the screenshots, you know incredible it looks, and no amount of words will do Zee's work justice. The game sounds just as magnificent as it looks, featuring the talents of Darren Korb and Ashley Barrett, who have created a soundtrack as soothing as it blood-pumping. You see that original soundtrack for sale up there? Buy it.There's not much else I can say about Transistor, except that feels like the most complete and well-polished experience I've ever had the sheer joy of playing. It's a near-perfect and complete work of art, one that easily earns every cent of your money and second of your time.

												The atmosphere, as you might expect from the trailers, is incredible. What you won't understand from the footage is just how finely woven the storytelling is for a game whose main character has had her voice removed in the story. It starts in medias res (in the middle of the action), and unfolds plot points through beautifully illustrated flashbacks, the transistor's dialogue, and even the game mechanics themselves. Your skills are traces of people, and as you use these skills in more varied ways you unlock more information about the person the trace is from, the world they lived in and the cabal of characters they came in contact with. Combat is clever and surprisingly fast paced for the sort that lets you jump into a paused planning mode. Take advantage of the Sandbox planning areas, Red's humming mechanic and unlocking all the information in traces and limiters. Though your character can't speak, her personality is revealed through the transistor, her input into computer terminals, her actions or lack of during cutscenes, and the soundtrack that you will absolutely not regret buying. The story is deep enough to make sense and propel you forward while still leaving you wide open to theory crafting at the end. My only complaint is that I don't want to leave the game and the <10 hours of gameplay, while bittersweetly satisfying, will not be enough to appease you once you've fallen head over heels in love with this world.

2, 2014
												One of the best games i've ever played.It's a short game, you can complete in about 5/6 hours, where you fight sets of enemies (called "Process") as you progress through the story.You fight the enemies with your abilities, that the game calls Functions. The interesting thing about it is that even though you have a set of abilities, the same ability can be used in different ways: as an active ability, as an upgrade to another ability or as a passive ability. The game tells you what each ability do in each of those 3 roles. This leads to an endless number of possible ways you can combine your abilities. Not only that but it does it in a very good way, since there's not exactly an obvious choice of "loadout" and multiple alternatives are viable and effective to fight against the enemies. It really leaves space for you to use the abilities the way you fell more comfortable with. In the beginning it might be hard to figure out which abilities to use and how you will use them, the amount of choices you have is a little bit overwhelming, but as you play you will learn the weaknesses and strengths of each one until it's really no longer a problem. The game helps you with that, you are given only a few abilities to use at the start and you unlock new ones little by little.The combat itself is very innovative. You can use your abilities just pressing its button, just like in an mmo or Diablo. But more often than not, you will be using the Turn() mode. In this mode the game is paused and you can plan your movements and the attacks you will do, then execute the plan. The game has no difficulty selection, but you can customize how hard the game can be by using the Limiters, some of them buff your enemies while others nerf the player in general. By choosing Limiters, the combat will be harder but you will receive more experience and level up faster as a result.This makes up the core mechanics of the game, which i greatly enjoyed.But an excellent mechanic is not only what this game has to offer.The visuals and the art style is incredible, i would dare to say it is the most beautiful isometric game i've ever saw. Really really good. The soundtrack is also very good, not only it is good on a musical standpoint as it also fits the game perfectly and contributes greatly for a better immersion.I would highly recommend this game to anyone, if you are still not sure, wait for a sale, otherwise buy it full price. And you may also want to grab the soundtrack. You will want it after playing the game.

er 23, 2016
												It's hard to review a game with such little flaws. The story is a masterpiece, could easily be extrapolated to become a critic of our society, the soundtrack, jesus ♥♥♥♥ing christ the soundtrack, if you played you know there aren't words to describe it. The graphics are ridiculously beautiful, scenarios are quite detailed, enemies not much but that's to be expected, won't say why since it would be a spoiler.Okay, so, to sum it up pretty poorly, the game is about a utopian city where the people who live there can shape it however they wish, until something goes wrong. You are in charge of finding out what went wrong and why. At first i thought it would be something like, "yeah well theres the supervillain who wanted the power all to himself" or something along those lines, as it usually is. I was wrong. Oh boy, i was.Without further ado, let's get to numbers and proper review of the game's aspects.Pros:+ Brilliant backstory+ Amazing soundtrack+ Gameplay mechanics mixes a lot of many games together, making it unique+ Very well designed, looks almost like a piece of art coming to life+ Has good replay value, since it has a "new game+" like feature+ You can customize your abilities to match your playstyle+ You can customize the difficulty setting of the game by messing exactly with which part you want easier/harder+ Very interesting way to develop character backgroundsCons:- Rather short game, you can finish the main story in about 5 hours- Even if you can choose the abilities, some of them are overpowered, making them almost mandatory- Battles become a chore after certain abilities are unlocked- Price is a little high for a game so shortWith about 26 hours into it, i have unlocked everything there was to unlock and got all achievements the game had. Even though the price is not ideal, it's still worth the extra effort, and if you can buy it on a good sale, the price problem is gone.Final score: 8.6/10. If you're a fan of games with more thought provoking storylines, or like new/unexplored combat systems, this game is for you.

y 1, 2015
												Highly recommended. Transistor has an amazing audio-visual style and a strong emotional story. The gameplay is fused into its sci-fi world, and everything about it is blended with jargon from informatics, computers, programming, technology etc. The combat system is evolved, engaging and suprisingly deep and diverse.The Good(1) Art-style is awesome. (2) Music is fantastic, original and merged with the story. Red, the protagonist, is a singer who has lost her voice, and for that reason there's a dedicated "Hum" button, where the game pauses and Red hums to background music! (3) Combat system is a very interesting and well balanced blend of real-time with pause-and-give-orders: You can fight in real time (which is hard!) or you can use the "Turn()" command to give orders which are then executed sequentially by Red while her enemies are slowed down (nearly stopped). After that, Turn() requires several seconds to recover before you can use it again; it the meanwhile you can't use any abilities and just need to run around in real-time avoiding enemies.The Bad(1) The story can be confusing. Despite the very few characters, it's often hard to understand why Red, the protagonist, does what she does. It took me two playthroughs and reading a thorough guide, to understand what was going on. Nevertheless, you can "breeze" through the game just for the feeling without losing much, but understanding the story adds to the emotional experience. (2) The sci-fi jargon --informatics, computers, programming, technology-- can also be confusing. I have some skill in the department and it wasn't all that easy for me either. The GUI is good at explaining things, but you gotta spend some time to check things out. (3) The game is not good at revealing the depth of its combat system. Also, with the main story being relatively short, you can reach the ending and beat the game without needing to grasp the mechanics. My second playthrough (NG+) was much more entertaining, as was doing all the optional "Tests" offered.*** Comparison to Bastion: I liked Bastion's narrator better, as well as the delivery of the story, which was way simpler. Also, I believe that Bastion was better at hooking you up into its gameplay. Transistor has much better combat system, but it's not so good at hooking you up. Transistor's visuals, music and "world" are much more interesting.*** I played this for more than 20hrs, completed the story twice (first play-through and NewGame+) and got almost all the achievements.

content:
, 2014
												Short Version:Does this game generally objectively fulfill perceived goals: Yes.Should you buy this game: Yes.How does it chalk up to Bastion?: They have similarities, but Transistor stands on its own. In some ways, it is superior and more mature than Bastion, while in other ways, Bastion has an edge in storytelling.Long Version:Transistor is beautiful. Transistor is inspired by Bastion in many ways, and that's abundantly clear from the get-go. From the similar ever-present voice of Logan Cunningham, to the angled top-down approach, Supergiant is definitely playing to their strengths.Transistor, visually, has a great feel. Pre-rendered maps have stunning detail and effort. While Bastion in places had a pieced together, stylized look in the Calamity-stricken ruins of Caelondia, the city of Cloudbank is fully fleshed, and takes on strange and interesting changes as the enemies of the game - "The Process" - make their mark on the city.Transistor is linear. That's okay. Linear is not always bad, though your adventure feels more or less on rails throughout the entire game. Some may consider this a flaw. People coming from Bastion, however, probably are not expecting much here. It is, however, worth noting that Transistor does -not- have different endings.Transistor's soundtrack is breathtaking - the music alone easily justifies half the cost of the game. The music played in various scenarios takes on different variations depending on circumstances, and the world becomes muted and quiet while the haunting voice of the protagonist - Red - takes center stage during the Turn(). Musically inclined peoples want this soundtrack, if not the game too.Transistor is short. People generally expect to get more hours from a video game than they can realistically play in a day without a binge session. If it were full price, that might be a problem. Fortunately, the nice low price of 20$ means that a 6-8 hour playthrough (assuming you do not rush through content) will strike a sweet spot. The game values your time and effort, and nothing in the game feels like "busy work", nor does anything feel like filler. The game, contrary to what some claim, feels like pure substance.Transistor is a bargain - the game is effortlessly worth more than it costs.Transistor's combat is varying shades of complex. In time, you will find that some abilities may feel somewhat superfluous and certain abilities like Void() become more or less necessities in gameplay with highest difficulty settings enabled - "limiters" in game. The game does an admirable job of respecting the intellect of its player - there are very few tutorials or listed instructions in actual gameplay, and you are encouraged and rewarded with bits of story and background when you experiment with the various "Functions" that are made available to you throughout.Transistor leaves a lot to interpretation. If you prefer a story where everything neatly ties up in the end, and you are left satisfied and ready to move on to the next big thing in your day, Transistor will leave you unsettled. The game offers a peak into a dire moment in Cloudbank's story, and as you play a mystery unfolds that descends into chaotic circumstances that few could possibly predict. Because the game is short, there is ultimately only so much that can be done to lend clarity to some of the events of the story, and you will likely be left with questions that will leave you scratching your head for days to come.That's not to say the game is pointless, absurd, or nonsensical. It is simply the sort of game that seems more or less designed to haunt you, be that good or bad.The game, despite it's great strengths also suffers from limitations of the developers. Transistor's probably largest flaw is that the story is TOLD to you, and not SHOWN as well as some may like. Earned story tidbits more or less being fed in the form of static images and a few paragraphs of vague background information begin to feel like a substitute or a placeholder where something better could have been implemented - brief cutscenes or playable intermissions where we can watch events unfold in other places. It feels like a missed opportunity to elevate the methods used to tell the story. Why it's done this way, I can only guess - this is the first title that Supergiant Games has self-published, and only their second game. They're a very small name in gaming for now, and that means that a lot of the things we may expect and take for granted in other games are not options to them.All that said, I can wrap it up. It's a gorgeous, fun, interesting and expressive game that is presented at a price so low that you really can't lose. It's flaws are minor enough that it becomes easy to forget about them and simply bask in the enjoyable combat mechanics and the sultry tones of the sword in your hands as you explore the computer-like city of Cloudbank.

												Transistor is a game that drives my heart into the world of cyberpunk and dystopian science fiction. It’s not just about gorgeous presentation and addictive combat, but I also realize the fault of human creation.The more you advance in Transistor, the more you understand how the truth of the Cloudbank. Most of the time, Transistor is your main weapon and storyteller. Transistor also gives you strong narrative, telling what is going on, and comments on your interaction even each terminal is worthwhile to read.As you fight against The Process, the main feature is shined out. Transistor’s combat can split into real-time approach and turn-based approach which give you planning phase to set your position, target, and set of skills. The variety of skill as you progress through the game make Transistor has unique combat and gives player’s choice to try out their own skill build. Even the limiter feature which works like player debuff, and test rooms offer challenge and thinking rather than spamming for win. However, it can be frustrated for cool down after turn mode is used as you may have to run around in small area while some enemies can constantly harm you. It is just minor issue which you can get over with once you get your perfect build.Transistor is such a unique and great experience. Not just engaging combat, but I fell in love in polished art design, story, and memorable soundtracks which create what people like in the game. And I’m pretty sure you will enjoy much as I do once you get deeper into The Cloudbank.

content:
, 2014
												Following up Bastion would be a hard act for anybody, so it can be a forgiven a bit that Transistor is what I'd call Supergiant Games' sophomore slump. It's a game that leans a little too heavily on the familiar, yet seems a bit unsure of how it wants to present itself as a separate new entity. You've got your talking Transistor which functions as the game's narrator, you've got Jen Zee's unmistakably fantastic art direction, and you've got Darren Korb's trancey-blues fusion soundtrack, and all those elements come together fairly well for the most part. Transistor is a gem to behold and contains nothing but fantastic audio candy for days and days. Unfortunately the gameplay and story lack the shine and polish Bastion had. The combat is a good mixture of real-time and turn-based combat, allowing you to use skills at the press of a button or queue them up to unleash with certain timing. Customizability is a huge factor since every skill in the game can be active, support, or passive, and the combinations are almost endless. That said, with all the strategy a system like this could bring, it's fairly easy to bulldoze through almost all enemy encounters with a few of the skills you start with, and even easier once you start playing around with combinations. While discovering these ridiculous combinations is fun and rewarding though, it throws every bit of strategy the game promises and throws it out the window fairly early, and by the end of the game battles become tedious. Transistor's storytelling takes a different approach to Basion's. You're immediately thrown into Transistor's world without much of an idea of what's going on and you're railroaded through the adventure at a Final Fantasy XIII, purely linear breakneck pace. The story does have a decent resolution, but the world, characters, and motivations of Transistor's cast are either too vague or hard to grasp. Everybody talks as if the player knows what's going on and there's not much expository dialog to help clear much up. Each skill you obtain has a character profile associated with it, but these provide mostly flavor text and there are some questions that are simply left unanswered and a plotline or two that get completely lost in the shuffle. Transistor is in no way bad, but it's easy to feel disappointed with it. The breakneck pace with which it presents itself and the abrupt ending make it feel almost rushed in some ways, even with as gorgeous as it is on the whole. If you're undecided on it right now, I'd say wait for a sale.

y 22, 2015
												Transistor, aesthetic wise, think Blade Runner meets Cowboy BeBop.  But that really isn't a fair description at all.   First of all I want to say I am not a big RTS fan at all.  So I was very much on the fence about Transistor.  I got it in the Winter Sale of 2014 and just got around to playing it and boy was it a treat.  Gameplay aside this game is ART.  The visuals are stunning and the soundtrack is stellar as we have come to expect with composer Darren Korb of the previous SuperGiant game Bastion acclaim.  Ashely Barrett (also from Bastion fame) has some outstanding vocals as well.  I am not going to compare this game to Bastion they are both good in thier own right.  I enjoyed the Real time/Planning kind of gameplay Transistor brought to the table.  Really unique.  It's a great game albeit short.  I didn't do any extras or training missions and the story took me about 4 hours.  The story (to me) was kinda ambigous and convoluted, but I think that was the point to get people discussing theories and what they interpreted it as.  All in all it's a great game, pick it up if you want to see some gorgeous visuals, hear some great music, and have a unique experience only SuperGiant can deliver :)

If you prefer a story where everything neatly ties up in the end, and you are left satisfied and ready to move on to the next big thing in your day, Transistor will leave you unsettled. The game offers a peak into a dire moment in Cloudbank's story, and as you play a mystery unfolds that descends into chaotic circumstances that few could possibly predict. It feels like a missed opportunity to elevate the methods used to tell the story. Why it's done this way, I can only guess - this is the first title that Supergiant Games has self-published, and only their second game. They're a very small name in gaming for now, and that means that a lot of the things we may expect and take for granted in other games are not options to them.All that said, I can wrap it up. It's a gorgeous, fun, interesting and expressive game that is presented at a price so low that you really can't lose. content:
9, 2015
												Sometimes, after playing a lot of competitive multiplayer games, you just have to step back and enjoy something much more authentic like Transistor. This game allowed me to really appreciate a story based single-player game as I was drowned in a breathtaking world with its own unique atmosphere and gameplay.During my first few minutes in to the game, I instantly recognized the amount of work Super Giant Games put into Transistor's presentation. The visual aspect of the game consists of beautiful hand drawn art, a vibrant colour scheme, smooth animation, and excellent character design. The auditory aspect is also just as outstanding as the visuals; the soundtracks consists of a mix of haunting guitar rifts and electronic music which captures the mood of the empty and haunting city of Cloudbank, and the voices and sound effects are also on par with this.The gameplay is also unique and makes the game more strategic compared to Super Giant's previous game, Bastion. The turn system allows you to plan your attacks, but there's also a mix of mechanical play with this, such as having to decide the best times to switch to turn mode or real time. I also really enjoyed how the functions worked (which are the skills), as there are thousands of possible combinations as you can use, since you can either use the function as an active, a passive, or you can stack the function on another function to add a unique property. I also liked how they added limiters in the game to make the game much more challenging in a unique way that rewards the player.

It is simply the sort of game that seems more or less designed to haunt you, be that good or bad.The game, despite it's great strengths also suffers from limitations of the developers. Transistor's probably largest flaw is that the story is TOLD to you, and not SHOWN as well as some may like. Earned story tidbits more or less being fed in the form of static images and a few paragraphs of vague background information begin to feel like a substitute or a placeholder where something better could have been implemented - brief cutscenes or playable intermissions where we can watch events unfold in other places. It feels like a missed opportunity to elevate the methods used to tell the story. Why it's done this way, I can only guess - this is the first title that Supergiant Games has self-published, and only their second game. They're a very small name in gaming for now, and that means that a lot of the things we may expect and take for granted in other games are not options to them.All that said, I can wrap it up. It's a gorgeous, fun, interesting and expressive game that is presented at a price so low that you really can't lose. It's flaws are minor enough that it becomes easy to forget about them and simply bask in the enjoyable combat mechanics and the sultry tones of the sword in your hands as you explore the computer-like city of Cloudbank.

												Absolutely loved this game.While you simply cannot beat Bastion's soundtrack or narrator, Transistor's soundtrack does not disappoint, and the Hum feature is really cool. I enjoyed the world and storyline, though both can be confusing at times.The battle/customization system is awesome, based on Functions used in Active, Upgrade, or Passive slots, in addition to the given Turn() Function which allows you to pause battle and plan out your next few moves. Trying out different combinations is encouraged through optional tests the player can complete for experience at various points throughout the game, as well as receiving information on a Function's associated character as you use it in different slots, but the game allows you to use your tried-and-true combos enough that you don't feel you're constantly having to switch things around (though I found it fun to). Once you beat the game, you have the option to start Recursive Play, where you keep your User Level and all Functions/Upgrades and start the game anew, earning the same Functions as before allowing their use in more than one slot. I enjoyed this second playthrough, though I really wish that you could continue the original story instead of restarting. COMPLETELY, 100% worth the money if you pick it up on sale, and I highly recommend you do.

This is pretty crucial to most combat in the game so you'll tend to spam it as soon as it comes off cooldown. The story when you first start is pretty confusing and I pretty much had no idea what was going on until I was done with a 1/3 of the game and the game isn't really straightforward with the storytelling so you pretty much have to go through with the tidbits that are given to you at the beginning and just complete the puzzle by either completing files or going through OVC terminals or just listening to what the characters say during their dialogues. The customization allows you to format abilities you can use during a battle, augment those abilities onto another ability that enhances it in some way, or you can decide to augment it onto your body. You can pretty much switch however way you want it anytime during the game provided you get to a terminal which is pretty common throughout the whole game. Transistor is short, you could probably finish the whole game in around 10 hours but sweet jesus it's 10 really good hours without even touching the Recursion aspect. Transistor is GOTY material, buy it, try it, cry at how short it is.

content:
1, 2015
												Transistor is an iteration of the great top-down 2d action RPG game Bastion. Once again Supergiant Games delivers a perfectly themed fantasy world (sci-fi this time), with beautiful handdrawn graphics, and a superb soundtrack from Darren korb. Once again the story just starts from scratch, and is told to you bit by bit as you progress through the game. The story has the same metaphorical vagueness about it, that lets your imagination play it's part, and make it feel more personal and relevant.At first glance it would seem that this game would be a no-brainer to recommend for anyone who liked Bastion, but there's quite a big game changer in Transistor: Turn based combat. Yup, you have the ability to stop time and plan your moves, and then "release" time again and watch your actions unfold. This comes at the penalty of not being able to use your weapons (functions) for some seconds afterwards. That is unless you've applied a certain upgrade to a function, then you can always use that particular weapon. But you only gain this upgrade later in the game, and you'll only have 1 instance of it, unless you're on your second playthrough.Personally, I felt the turn based element just increased the tactical depth of the combat, so I see it as an improvement, but I can see how it might put some people off. You could of course choose to use it as little as possible, but I reckon you'd be severely handicapped, and some parts would be impossible (speed tests e.g.).The only mentionable complaint I have is that there is no "Retry with same loadout" option during the tests. It's pretty annoying having to reconfigure all the slots from scratch every time.The game is pretty short (6-7 hours including all the tests I reckon), but if you like the game as much as I did, you wanna recurse() the story as soon as you've completed it, and get all the achievements, which btw are relevant and very achieveable :)90%

content:

												Well, I just finished my Recursion and can now finally review the game.The fights are basically played in an arena - a closed area on the map - and require a lot of thought in skill preparation and use as well as character placement.Their are two ways to wage a fight. Either you go the classic active way (like any action game), or you can use the Turn() function which allows you to stop time and plan your attacks at leisure.While in Turn(), everyone freezes and a bar appears at the top of the screen, this bar represent the total of actions you can take (for those who know of it, imagine Legend of Legaia's system). Moving and attacking eats a part of the bar depending of the skill and isn't done right away, instead you plan all hte attack which will be carried out when you finish the Turn(). The actions are then done at lightning speed, often taking a number of enemies to the grave at once with good planning.About the skills :You will equip skills (which you acquire by leveling and by finding people) at savepoint, in up to 4 active slots.Every skill is totally different from another both visually and practically. One can debuff a group of enemies in an area while the other will make you invisible for a while.Then you can equip those skills as passives for the active skills or for yourself. A skill that makes you drop explosives packets on the ground as active will increase the damage and blast radius of another as passive. Character passives can increase your total HP, reduce damage taken, reduce cost of abilities during Turn()...The game isn't too short, but not really long. It took me 7 hours to complete my first run and 9 hours to Recurse through the story. Recursion is basically New Game+ wherre you keep everything and replay the story while the enemies are end-game level and randomized through the areas.The scenario can seem confused, but is very enjoyable with many things to learn.Apart from the Sandbox - which give acces to a practice area and a number of tests as well as some miscellaneous stuff, a big one being the jukebox - there is no side content.The art is sublime and serves very well the game. The music nicely compliments the action and events throughout the game and is a jewel to listen to. I give a solid 9.5/10 for this well crafted game. Really enjoyed it.

content:
, 2015
												Before we begin, let us establish something that should be obvious from the game's title, but apparently isn't to some players: THIS IS NOT BASTION 2Playing it like it was Bastion 2 can only lead to frustration and disaappointment. To appreciate Transistor, you must approach it respectfully, on its own terms, and not guided by your own expectations, as, really, you should be doing with every game worth talking about.While it uses some of the same innovative mechanisms that were introduced in Bastion, it is not, nor does it try to be, more of the same - something I admire with Supergiant's production that, apparently, some players of the game find frustration with. They could've easily printed money by making a Bastion 2, but chose to make something original instead. How can you not admire such a departure from the unscrupulous money grab that is sadly becoming the norm in this hobby?I've likely already gifted you this game if we're on reasonably friendly terms. But for everyone else, allow me to say that, speaking as an experienced gamer, this is my favourite game. It is, in a word, perfection, and those of you who know how critical I can be of these things should know I do not say that lightly. Perfectly harmonized design, art direction, music, writing, everything. The team at Supergiant, earning themselves a place as my personal favourite developers, and in any case an honoured spot on the true A-list, have here created another superbly crafted game that I warmly encourage everyone to try and experience.

content:
6, 2015
												A couple of things - one - Puzzlefox's excellent thumbs down review adequately summarizes many of my complaints about the game, lack of variety, almost non-existent story, a tedious rather than rewarding challenge area, and simplistic enemies.  So there is that - having loved bastion to tag this game with any of those things (which it excelled at) is really disheartening. However aside from those issues I had some of my own (ignore my logged playtime, I got in about 3-4ish hours off the books.I still haven't finished this game. I may come back and change my review if I can ever stand to drudge my way through it. Until such a time - here are the reasons why despite loving bastion and SuperGiant; I consider this game a misfire and would only recommend it to people when it's on sale or if they simply want to support the studio without buying multiple copies of bastion. Combat.I really like turn-based games. I am enjoying my third playthrough of Invisible Inc at the time of writing this review, I also actually mucked around with the challenge modes and New Game + in Bastion, so I can get into some hack n slash. What I can't get into, no matter how hard I try, is violently switching between those two formats over and over in a fight. Or more accurately, I can't get into doing a "turn" and then running around or hiding for a few seconds while it recharges. It breaks my immersion, feels tedious, and honestly makes every fight in the game a chore. I know some people are really into this; and it clicks for them. I am deeply envious of those people because if the game had full turn-based I am positive I would have at least had the stomach to make it to the end.Story/NarrationI am combining these two, because I have yet to make it to the second boss (I am assuming there are three) in any playthrough and the second nail in the coffin is the narration. I love Logan as a voice actor, he essentially sold Bastion for me, and I'm not saying he needs to display a huge range in the early game. However - dribbling the story out slowly is simply less effective for me when he sounds so utterly emotionless and bored while delivering every single line. His dry quips never land, and honestly it's like they woke him up after trapping him in a sound booth and made sure he only recorded lines while still wiping the sleep from his eyes. Again - this might change in Act 3 or something - but if you bore me in the beginning I may never make it that far.Style.Initially I was really loving the art design. I still love the menus, music, and overall style. However one thing I lamented is that as I move from one section of the city to the next, I can barely tell any real difference. Part of what worked in Bastion was that each area felt distinct. With this game each area might have some slight variation, but the overwhelming same-ness of it all started to really wear on me. It didn't help that the random white blocks that popped up detracted from any sense of geography or style. In Bastion it was shop-carts, barrels, and plants. In this game it's just white blocks. White blocks. White Blocks. I'm not sure what they were going for here but it definitely contributed to my overall boredom.So inevitably it comes to this. If I had to rate it on a scale, I'd give it a 5/10. A well-polished game from a really good developer that simply misses several of the targets I really needed it to hit. However I don't get a scale, I just get a recommend or not. I don't recommend it, certainly not for $20. No one is sadder than me that I feel this way, and I sincerely hope their next game wins me back over.

												Transistor.I honestly can't tell which one, Bastion or Transistor were more to my liking. Both have their awesome unique mechanics and stunning music.When you start the game, you don't have a main menu, instead you are put right into the game. This really took my by surprise. I think you'll understand what I mean once you launch the game.So, lets get on with it.The Plot: 10/10Just like in Bastion, you are thrown right into the game without any introduction. Just a gal with a sword-like object which apparently talks. First I had no idea what was talking to me. The further you go into the story, the more is revealed, along with the backstory of Red (the main character, the musician). Soon it appears that 4 villans, the Camerata, those who basically own the city Cloudbank. Not only that, they are mostly scientists who care for the city, but made a mistake, and... well, you'll find out.Gameplay: 9/10Bastion had a right-left-midbutton gameplay, while here you get abilities that you use. Not only that, it is also followed with Turn() feature, a planning feature that allows you to stop time and make actions like walking and using abilities for the price of Turn() potential (lets call it that). For instance, a Breach() ability (your very first ability you have access to) uses 20 Turn().Not only that, you get some introduction to different characters who these abilities belonged to. For example, Red's ability is Breach(), an ability that stuns the target and makes it more vulnerable for 1.6 secs. Another one was a racer, when you used the transistor to "absorb" his essence, you retrieved an ability that allows you to blink. Furthermore, you can read info on these abilities that reveal about the character.Each ability can also be used as a passive or an upgrade to a different abilities. They can be swapped at any time when you get to an access point.And of course, remember the Shrine in Bastion? Here you have so called "Limiters", they work exactly the same as those things in the Shrine, except they also reveal info on the "Process" if used.Music: 10/10I won't comment on this. No point.Visuals: 10/10Seriously, the visuals are just amazing. Some may complain tho, that they don't like cyberpunk stuff, but to me, the art in this is majestic. The lights, the sketches, everything deserves a 10 in my opinion.Duration: 7/10Sadly, its rather short, but if you play with limiters you may get a longer enjoyment from this. That's exactly what I did with Bastion. Yet Transistor is still shorter than Bastion. I really wish it either had a continuation or just a longer gameplay. That may ruin the plot however.Replayable? Yes, definitely. Its worth replaying. Unlike Bastion, you don't have to grind here to get levels (because you can't, lol).Overall:I really want to give it 10/10, but I can't. I honestly just can't. I want it to be a bit longer, I want to get more enjoyment, maybe have a reality where Process comes from, where I can destroy its core, where I can have some sort of a choice like in Half-Life at the very end, or... I don't know. I just feel the urge for this to be longer.So any way.9/10, I can't wait for Supergiant games to release a new game. Maybe soon, maybe later, maybe next year (I actually heard they are working on a new game to be released in 2017).TL;DR Transistor is awesome, has great music, gameplay mechanics and great plot. If you feel like you need a game that would allow you to relax and feel some enjoyment, then this is it. I am a Dota 2 player myself, and nothing relaxed me more than Bastion and Transistor (especially transistor, tbh). Go buy it.

content:
er 2, 2016
												Transistor may be the classiest, most stylish and beautiful game I've ever played. It also seems very innovative. It's an evolution on the super-saturated acrylic painting style of Bastion (Supergiant's previous game), incorporating an intricate 1920s art deco interpretation of neon turquoise Tron glow, visually somewhat similar to Bioshock.The sound track is an integral part of the beauty. Not at all just background noise, it's closely integrated into the context. It's smoothly haunting with the protagonist character humming soulfully along at the push of a button (strangle compelling).This game quite closely resembles it's predecessor in many ways:
Both are top down, isometric view.  Poignant, with pretty little side-on 2D cutscenes that augment the in-play storytelling. Tales of personal loss and societal/city devastation, picking up (or picking through) the pieces. Disembodied voice-over narration from another character, but one who's physically present in context this time.  Mute protagonist, again an explanation is worked in here excellently.  There are unlocks that make play harder (for slightly more experience gain), as well as collecting new abilities.But it departs from Bastion's pure, practised skill - aim and click, continuously rolling action bonanza - by injecting a kind of seamless turn planning mechanism into the real time action. This allows, and demands, far more tactical thinking in the heat of battles. It's rewarding as you can escape tight spots in style and beat heavy odds. Plus, of course, this gives plenty of time to stop, think and analyse the situation. Great for those of us who don't always quite have the mental processing speed of fighter pilots.The abilities, known as "functions", form the core of the game experience. They are not only used as novel new active attacks, but also modifier upgrades to any other ability you have. Or, as a passive abilities that are always active. Thus there is a combinatorial explosion of possibilities as you proceed to accumulate them.The huge, buried depth of game mechanics (that must have taken a whole lot of careful design and coding) reminds me most of Magicka's spell system. There, elements are combined in real time to be blasted out like guitar chords. But composing new Transistor skill combinations is a separate  setup process done at "Access Point" checkpoints. I found all the descriptions a little hard to juggle mentally while shuffling between the different information screens. It's also time consuming, and a little bit more fiddly than necessary, taking me at least as long, overall, as the actual fighting. So probably too long, unless this suits your mindset somewhat, with the play flow thoroughly interrupted. The game is all about figuring out synergistic load-outs and combo strategies.Players are incentivised to try out many combinations, since there are narrative expanding character biography snippets which are unlocked by using each new ability once (in combat) in each of the 3 types of slot. There's also opportunities to quickly test out ideas and practice, away from the main story progression, in a literal beach themed "Sandbox" area. So you're unlikely to stick to one favourite setup for long. It would be real shame and I'm not sure how much that would even be possible. The battles are quite varied, so will often demand quite different approaches. Enemy types are randomly varied to an extent too, on each re-try (or re-play).Each ability embodies archetypal personality traits of a particular character and they are woven into the story ark to be picked up along the way. It's pretty clever, and really gives a sense of double meaning, that everything and everyone is a metaphor for parts of a computer system, perhaps, like (the original) Tron. Programming functions personified, or vice versa.The plot sets out like "Kill Bill" (2003), but, as details are incrementally expanded via a variety of interactions, a very nuanced exploration of big societal themes is rendered, with the antagonists being sympathetic, tragic and their purpose and motivations understandable. At large, it is a reflection on the potential flaws of an absolute (participatory) democracy, even in an otherwise utopian environment. Here, the 'Process' (collective name for the robot enemies) also feels duplicitous - sounding almost like they are talking about understanding (and subverting) the politic process. Then, of course, the dangers of concentrated power - how small personal flaws might cause everything to unravel. Here, "The Camerata" has resonance, to me, of the Khmer Rouge, or some other revolutionary force, that accidentally caused huge losses when applying its ideology.So there is certainly much depth to this game, on many levels, with no doubt many real world references tied in. e.g. "Royce Bracket" may be named for Winston W. Royce, computer scientist who coined the term 'software engineering'. "Young Ladies" perhaps a tip to Neal Stephenson cyberpunk novel "The Diamond Age: Or, A Young Lady's Illustrated Primer"...? Talk of "The Country", a reference to Shakespeare's line: "The undiscovered country from whose bourn, No traveller returns"...?I don't feel that every single plot detail comes together in a perfectly defined way. Some things are deliberately left open to interpretation more than others, but I'm sure there will have been tweaks and compromises during development, interfering slightly with narrative sense. The mapping of game mechanics onto plot, while ever clever, and more thorough than most any other title, is not perfect. For example, the new game plus "recursion" mode doesn't seem able to have a direct, causal, logically consistent plot mapping (however much you overthink it). Regardless, Transistor definitely has a rewardingly complex, detailed story. One that will bear re-examination after first completion. Recursion is ideal for this. It also lets you carry on to pick up second copies of each ability function, for even more extreme setups. I personally reached max level just before finishing my second run, then picked up the final, challenging (10 limiters) achievement within 30 minutes of starting a second recursion. Perfectly paced for 100%-ing the Steam achievements; very satisfying.Value wise, it yielded about 40 hours of engaging play time for me. A large part of that was spent compulsively experimenting, as I like to do in such games (if they draw me in). This can be done in the context of regular combat, by simply restarting that section, back to your last access point where you can change things up again. But it is also the main utility of the sandbox, aside from trying to beat your highest single turn total damage figure (fun!). You reach this area via 'back doors' which crop up periodically in the main game. Also in this area are a whole bunch of differently structured tests and challenges, which pretty near double up the game's content and again encourage exploring and understanding the various functions: Time trials, escalating rounds of engagements to survive with a limited function set, etc. There are a half dozen logical puzzles that particularly tickled me, showing the flexibility of the turn() system. I wish there'd just been a few more... :-)

0, 2016
												Transistor is by far the best single-player experience I've had in a while. This game quickly immersed me in its unique world and original story. The soundtrack was stellar, Darren Korb did a wonderful job, not to mention Ashley Barret's vocals. The gameplay was very strategy-based but managed to stay well-paced enough to keep me interested. But what really made the game for me was Logan Cunningham's performance as the Transistor.The mere fact that the Transistor had a voice and personality was a great choice. Without him, the game would've felt lonely and fairly empty. The dynamic voice lines that made the Transistor react to situations made him feel a lot more real and I eventually fell infatuated with his and Red's relationship. The few other characters were also very well done, and the voice actors for them were all phenomenal.The gameplay, as said before, was unusual but fun. The "turn" mechanic I had not seen in a game before, but it was very well polished. I found myself trying out functions left and right for new effects which proved very useful, less I go through the entire game with Joust as an Active Function. Many of the fights were simple once I understood the core mechanics, so I added "Limits" in order to challenge myself. I found this to make some specific fights harder, while most stayed the same difficulty.The art and music added to the feel of the world's dystopian setting. I can't really describe this any better than it would be for you to just watch the trailer or pick up the game. Both are among the best that the video game industry has offered in this decade.If you are looking for a fairly short game with a lot of replayability, this is definitely the game for you. While not the most challenging game, it's definitely one worth playing through once or twice or five times. Between the breathtaking ambience, stunning performance, and astounding story and gameplay, Transistor is definitely one of my favorite games from the last few years.

content:
y 14
												If you're familiar with their other game, Bastion, then you have a good idea of what to expect.The game begins with the female main character, Red, pulling the sword named Transistor out of someone who has just been killed.  The rest of the game is essentially her seeking answers and battling with the fallout of that individual's death in this really unique and original world they've created. The game is extremely polished.  Like Bastion, they pair the visuals, music, and narration perfectly.  The game is absolutely dripping with style and attention to detail.  The combat system is really solid (and pretty challenging) as well.  You have four main abilities, or functions, that can be active at one time.  Each function you gain in the game contains the essence of a fallen individual of the city, whose lore you can read about once you possess it.  Each function has a main, secondary, and passive property.  Each one also requires a certain amount of memory, so which abilities you can run at the same time will depend on how much you have invested in increasing your max memory capacity.  The combat can be performed in real time or you can execute the turn() function and plan your moves ahead like a turn based game.  It's highly customizeable, albeit a little overwhelming at first (there is no tutorial but you do run have occasional access to a practice zone throughout).  I completed the playthrough without unlocking all of the passives or secondaries.  I guess that is supposed to draw you towards playing it again. My complaint is that the game is so compact.  It took me about 5 hours to complete.  I guess I played with minimum limiters (kind of like talents you pick to make certain aspects of the game more difficult in return for bonus xp), but if you need to have a multitude of these limiters to stretch out the experience of the game, then maybe somethings wrong.  Additionally, there are only a handful of enemy types (they get progressively more difficult as you advance in the game).  This leads to the combat getting a little repetitive in some combat filled areas.The game is very unique and well made, and I would absolutely recommend it.  However the $20 price-tag seems to have been made with the notion that the buyer would do multiple playthroughs.  I'd pick it up on sale instead.
