content:
y 14
												If you're familiar with their other game, Bastion, then you have a good idea of what to expect.The game begins with the female main character, Red, pulling the sword named Transistor out of someone who has just been killed.  The rest of the game is essentially her seeking answers and battling with the fallout of that individual's death in this really unique and original world they've created. The game is extremely polished.  Like Bastion, they pair the visuals, music, and narration perfectly.  The game is absolutely dripping with style and attention to detail.  The combat system is really solid (and pretty challenging) as well.  You have four main abilities, or functions, that can be active at one time.  Each function you gain in the game contains the essence of a fallen individual of the city, whose lore you can read about once you possess it.  Each function has a main, secondary, and passive property.  Each one also requires a certain amount of memory, so which abilities you can run at the same time will depend on how much you have invested in increasing your max memory capacity.  The combat can be performed in real time or you can execute the turn() function and plan your moves ahead like a turn based game.  It's highly customizeable, albeit a little overwhelming at first (there is no tutorial but you do run have occasional access to a practice zone throughout).  I completed the playthrough without unlocking all of the passives or secondaries.  I guess that is supposed to draw you towards playing it again. My complaint is that the game is so compact.  It took me about 5 hours to complete.  I guess I played with minimum limiters (kind of like talents you pick to make certain aspects of the game more difficult in return for bonus xp), but if you need to have a multitude of these limiters to stretch out the experience of the game, then maybe somethings wrong.  Additionally, there are only a handful of enemy types (they get progressively more difficult as you advance in the game).  This leads to the combat getting a little repetitive in some combat filled areas.The game is very unique and well made, and I would absolutely recommend it.  However the $20 price-tag seems to have been made with the notion that the buyer would do multiple playthroughs.  I'd pick it up on sale instead.

content:

												Transistor is a unique game to say the least. It expects the player to dig into its world and find the story for themselves, from reading skill descriptions to finding the terminals hidden in the nooks and crannies of the world. Super Giant flexes it's art muscles again and delivers some of the best 2D artwork in a game. It is truly a piece of art in motion. In addition to the top notch visuals, Transistor boasts one of the best gaming soundtracks. I find myself listening to the cd over and over while at work. The combat is a unique blend of strategy and an action game where the player can freeze time and plan out their attack on the "Process". As with Bastion, there are game modifiers that make this game tougher, making the need for this planning mode essential. I cannot praise this game enough. A run through of the story may be a brief 6 hours but it does not over stay its welcome and feels complete in almost every way. The game does not hold your hand and expects you as a player to dig into the world to get the most out of it.

You have a number of skills that can be either used as a primary skill (like hit 'em with the sword, or shoot a bolt of energy at a distant foe), or they can be slotted into a different primary (like add damage, or AoE to some other skill), or they can be used to provide a more general buff (you have a damage shield, or all backstabs do more damage). y 25
												Okay, where do I begin...Overall, yes, I would recommend it, just because Supergiant made a unique experience with a definitive art style.That being said, the game to me is very flawed, especially when you compare it to its spiritual predecessor, Bastion:1) This game is incredibly short. You can beat it in 3 hours, if not less. There is a time and place for games as short as this (Journey, where replays are encouraged). 2) You spend half the game going through a few maps, get to a certain area, and lo and behold your final destination was JUST PAST where you started the game in the opposite direction. You spend the second half retracing your steps through a disfigured Cloudbank 3) Combat and customization are very limited. Combining your abilities in new, unique ways was actually rather satisfying, especially when you discover a new combination to trounce enemies ahead of you. Other than that, there is almost no character progression other than increasing your RAM (literally) and junctioning moves together.4) There were two voices (if you don't count Red's occasional humming), and I didn't feel an emotional connection to either of them because of how they were voiced. It was as if they took a page out of William Shatner's book of acting on pausing mid-sentence, coupled with very monotonous expressions. 5) Biggest complaint about the story though has to be how disconnected I was to all of it. I will say that the ending was well done, though. I can see the rationale behind it. 6) There was almost no tutorial to speak of. I had to figure out almost everything by myself. Any tutorial that was there was hidden behind technical lingo resembling computer code, which I suppose fits the game's style.6/10. Support your indie devs!

content:
y 8, 2015
												Supergiant is steadily becoming one of my favorite developers.  Bastion was amazing enough, but Transistor went even further with the strength of its art, music, sentimental narrative (Cunningham's voice is become quite iconic in its own right!), and more than anything, its mechanics with the customizable ability system, setting it apart from Bastion entirely.  Both of their games make me realize why I now prefer smaller companies in gaming: a smaller number of dedicated people making a smaller game seems much more likely to never lose sight of their creative focus, and the end product is often a more memorable and rewarding experience than an big budget pile of trendy mediocrity where things either drag on to the point of tedium, or abruptly end in unfulfilled disappointment.My only regret is that I can't SPECIFICALLY explain why I love Transistor so much without spoiling what makes it so memorable, so I'm stuck with being vague.  All I can say is that I was extremely happy to play this game, despite...well, if anyone's finished the game, they know.  After the emotional reaction I got from Bastion, I would expect no less from Transistor.  They delivered exactly what I was hoping for, and let's just say there's a very good reason why I refused to buy this game without the soundtrack bundled in.  I only wish I could get an artbook to go with it.I really wish I didn't have to be so cryptic, but this is one of those games that you just do not spoil.  It's just so refreshing to see a game like this.

content:
3, 2014
												First, I'll do the quick one: If you liked Bastion, just buy this and go. The story and music may not be as good, but the art and gameplay are even better somehow. Go go go.For everyone else: Transistor is an absolute blast. The mix-and-match nature of the combat system leads to all sorts of fun experimentation. The semi-turn-based nature is also unlike anything I've never played before, and that alone makes this game worth trying out. It takes a bit for things to really open up, as you have very few powers for the opening bits of the game. But once you've got a sizable arsenal, this game shines like a diamond. The setting and story are delightfully unusual, but immediately familiar to anyone who enjoyed Tron or Reboot. Supergiant still knows how to make a wonderful soundtrack, and Logan Cunningham is a welcome return as the voice of the eponymous Transistor.So what's not so great? The back quarter of the game does drag a little bit, and if you want more info on the world than what the story offers you, prepare to do an awful lot of reading of people's bios in menus. And while the general storyline and ending are fine, they do leave a lot up to guesswork and interpretation. That's not to say it's too complex, just that I was left wanting to know a bit more. Twenty bucks may be a bit high for some, as the game can be beaten in a few sittings. On the other hand, it also means the game is very tight. There's little wasted space, and there is a "new game+" feature if you're just not done once you're done. I highly, highly recommend this game to just about anyone, even if action games aren't normally you're thing. The combat is very adjustable to be as forgiving or brutally punishing as you like, and the turn system often makes it as much about thinking through a problem as about running around like a maniac.

content:
2, 2014
												Transistor is staggeringly beautiful. All of the art, the setting, the music, the writing, all of it. It's also a pretty big departure from Bastion, which was made by the same developers. Yes, it's the same perspective, and there's an ever-present narrator, and the protagonist is mute, and you can increase the difficulty in a piecemeal fashion. The similarities end there. While you can play Transistor like an action game, it really requires more strategy than that. It has an active-pause system, where you can pause the action, plot out a set number of attacks or movements, and then unpause to see the results. The main loop ends up being pause, attack, run, which leads to a lot of guerilla tactics, more than straight out blasting enemies.The ability system is also super interesting. Every ability, whether it's a straight attack, or a cloak, or a bomb, can be used as-is, attached to another ability to lend it different qualities, or set as a passive bonus to yourself. This leads to a ton of combinations of attacks. Some work better than others, but they all feel unique. The limits to the system is that each ability has a memory requirement, and you have a memory limit. So you can stack up on a couple heavy hitters, but you limit yourself to a small number of attacks or bonuses. Likewise, you can have a full complement of attacks and bonuses, but you'll be lacking the most powerful of them. The one complaint I have is that the story is less straight forward than most video games. That doesn't mean it has a bad story, or that it's incomprehensible. It just takes more attention to the details than most. By the end, you'll probably get the gist of it, but expect to be a little disoriented.

												6/10This game was made by the makers of Bastion, so I had my hopes up. Sadly, while the graphic style and music is gorgeous, the story and gameplay are lacking cohesion. Similar to Bastion the action is controlled from isometric view and has lots of action rpg elements. There is real time combat and a turn mode, which stops the action and allows you to plan moves, which are then executed. Combat in real time is clunky, as the enemies move much to fast to evade, which forces the player into the turn mode. Consequently the game forces hit and run tactics. Stop the action, move close to the enemy, hit him with a few spells and run out of range. Rinse and repeat.One of the few good things about combat is the endless combinations of skills you can use. Each of the skills can be used as primary or enhancer of another skill. Sadly, you will end up using the 1-3 heavy hitting spells, without ever experimenting too much.All in all the developers did not succeed making this a cohesive game. Graphics and sound are great, gameplay and story telling are lacking. So you find yourself walking down pretty hallways without ever caring about the enemies you kill or knowing what exactly happened in this dystopian world.

												Transistor is made by SuperGiant Games, who are well known for their other masterpiece: Bastion. Both of these games have similarities with the isometric view, and feelings of being lonely. What Transistor does to break the mold and to step out from behind Bastion's shadow is amazing. It's sci-fi centric, and the musical selection of jazz is a great mood setter. Combat contrasts greatly from Bastion. In Bastion, the combat was fast-paced with very little cooldown and strategic plans. Transistor is all about the strategy standpoint as your attacks are slow as molasses, but brings in the mechanic of stopping time and planning attacks that will be automatically executed very fast after you set the plan. The artwork is beautiful and is very colorful. The levels are greatly detailed. The only voice heard during the game is the voice of the sword (i guess this will be a common theme among games by SuperGiant). If you are a fan of Bastion, this game is a must buy. If you didn't play Bastion and like games with strategic mechanics fused with some action, this is a perfect example.Transistor gets a 10/10 in my book.

er 30, 2015
												TL;DR: Transistor is a good game, and it will make you feel good.Transistor is a narrative-driven turn-based game that always seemed to be reminding me of the Tron universe. It's in the middle of an apocalypse, yet it has an eerie peacefulness about it. As you go about the world and destroy the monsters that are transforming the world, you can't help but take a step back and listen to the protaganist Red hum along to the background music, or look out over a pier for a few seconds and think about the history of a town you never knew. Something about this game calms you down. All of the mechanics seem to cater to a casual playstyle, although some moments can be very intense. Even the fast and reflexive combat system seems to be designed to make you breathe. You can take as much time as you want to plan out your moves, take a breather, take a break from the loud fighting music and explosions that are happening around you. It's calming.Of course, there's the narrator. The more I play games with great narrators like The Stanley Parable or Bastion (the latter of which was the same creator of Transistor). The narrator of Transistor is more personal than the two, though. It addresses the character, not the player. You are simply an observer to this story, and the narrator is unaware of your existence. This game is between Red and her love. You are granted the gift of watching. It's very touching and emotional at some points to realize that this story has to end somehow, and the few moments where the narrator leaves you feel so void and wrong. I'm not really sure what to say about the narration in this game, other than it's not really narration at all. There's just only one character with dialogue.As I said, everything in this game seems to be designed to make you feel calm and content. As evil and chaotic as some parts of this game are, all of it makes you feel reflective, nostalgiac almost. It's a good feeling. This game will make you feel good. It's a pity that I can't think of eloquent enough words to describe this game. Maybe it's because there's a woman screaming nonsense in the other room and I can't process thoughts (sorry if parts of this review don't make sense, but I honestly can't hear myself think), but I think mostly it's because when you find something that is truly beautiful, it doesn't take well to words, and although I wouldn't say this game is pure beauty and art, it is beautiful, and it is deliberate in its design. That's all I ask from a game.

												This is honestly one of the best games I have played in a very long time (Since Bastion). I think the problem that most people are seeing is that they wanted a Bastion 2, instead they got a completly diffrent game. The gameplay is fun to learn and use well, as if you make a mistake you're punished for it. Darren Korb has outdone himself, and Ashley Barrett has the voice of a goddess. Another problem people see is that you have to find the story for yourself. You can't just walk through everything and have the story layed out for you, you have to try new weapons and combinations, you have to search every alley, and even if it's only for a little remark made by the Transistor, it helps bring the world together. I can see how the game isn't for everyone, some people don't want to explore just for tiny remarks, or read about how the Antagonists chose certan people to make "disappear" and why those people were chosen. This game isn't a new Bastion, not by a longshot. Once you realize and accept that then the game really shows it's true colors. content:
1, 2014
												Transistor is an original, intelligent and lucid action RPG. The game revolves around Red, a singer whose voice was stolen by the Camerata, a group of individuals determined to Process a city that serves its people. Without formally identifying or constructing her as so, Red is presented as a strong female protagonist; this means she is without any of the clichés that so often inhibit this archetype. Supergiant masterfully pulls off a plot that gives her agency and the ability to sculpt a world inhabited by a cast of colourful characters whom the player learns about through the Functions() of the Transistor. The diversity of the characters, in particular, is to be commended: there are black and mixed-race, gay, lesbian and transgender characters.The Function() system is at the heart of the game; it allows the player to combine different attacks and abilities in either primary, upgrade, or passive slots, resulting in a unique experience with approximately 22bn different combinations to be had. The system encourages experimentation, and so leads the player in to a kind of exasperating perfectionism: you want to get your loudout exactly right. The mix of frantic, fast-paced real time action and the suspended realm that Turn() provides to plan a sequence of moves is something quite unique and, surprisingly, it doesn't get tiresome. The enemies are varied enough to keep the battles interesting; they regularly upgrade themselves to match your own increasing prowess and there are enough different kinds to always provide a challenge.The soundtrack is both touching and transcendental; it encapsulates the changing pace of the game, from the arid mystery of a deserted Cloudbank at the beginning to the decaying ruins of a Processed world at the end. The mixture of electronica-esque synths, ambient Portal-like sounds and well-timed guitar riffs give suitable gravitas at just the correct moments. The music feels alive; it actively changes as you switch between states and the Turn() mode.It's the little things in Transistor that really complete it. Flavour text is what drives the realism and the allusions to software and programming are delightful to see. The different chapters of the plot and the scenes are strung together well enough so the entire game flows. Romanticised additions like the motorbike and the posters add a sense of fun  to the game and an importance to the role that Red has.The most striking element of the game is probably the artwork; the visuals are stunning and utilise different hues, colours, art styles and changes in lighting to illuminate Cloudbank. Cloudbank is a city inside a computer, but it feels very much real. The nuanced dichotomy of an organic, breathing world that is seen through the window of Red and the basic binary foundation that underlies the entire premise is linked delicately with endless, gorgeous pieces of artwork and cutscenes and this is remarkable.What makes Transistor a gem is the seamless integration of the idiosyncratic creativity of these elements -- music, artwork, plot and mechanics -- that would only be expected to find in the most successful of indie games, with the overall polish that usually only blockbuster games can pull off. The entire game has a glistening shine that suceeds in being both immersive and compelling, pulling the player into the digital utopia of Cloudbank and refusing to let them go. Certainly a niche game, but it can't be recommended enough.

12, 2016
												Transistor is the second game by Supergiant Games, developers of Bastion. I really enjoyed Bastion, but I definitely think it was flawed. Transistor builds upon everything in the best way possible, and is absolutely fanastic as a result.First thing is the art. Oh man it's amazing. There is so much diversity in colour and style for some of the setpieces, and all of the enemies are really unique. Without spoiling anything, I will also say the shift and direction of the artwork towards the ending of the game is really fitting and very well done. It's a really wonderful sight to take in while playing, and it's all backed by an amazing soundtrack. Supergiant actually just released the soundtrack on vinyl on their store and I grabbed a copy - it's a great pressing! Next thing; the story. One of my dislikes of Bastion was the cohesiveness of the story. I understand that they were trying something different with the narration, and that itself was very cool, but it was still too much for me to wrap my head around. When I finished the game for the first time, I barely had any understanding of what transpired. Transistor is a massive improvement. The presentation of the story and world have much more clarity, yet the storytelling itself is still very artistic and unique. The pacing is also much better than in Bastion, which I found dragged on a bit. While things did move a little fast in the beginning, I found I was able to piece together the setting by myself pretty accurately. However, I didn't like that tidbits of information on characters (which are the only way to really understand the setting of the narrative) are withheld until the player uses that character's function during an enemy encounter. This sucks because there are a limited amount of encounters throughout the game. Yes, there are more than enough encounters to reveal all information, however some encounters are obviously more difficult than others, so using an unfamiliar function may not be the best choice. I personally didn't encounter any problems, but this is still limiting to players who may not find the combat as easy.And that brings me to the combat. It took me a little over an hour to get used to it and understand it, (there's a very minimal tutorial on it) but once I got the hang of things, I really enjoyed it. It's a nice blend of real-time and turn-based elements. However, the whole home area system isn't well done. I think it would have been better if you could go to the beach area (an area where you can practice the combat) at any point in time. Also, it would have been nice if you were able to look up any function whenever you wanted to see how it worked instead of waiting to find one of those access points. Otherwise, the combat itself is very fluid and unique, and proves a challenge when limiters (options that increase difficulty by say, spawning more enemies, or limiting your powers etc.) are in use.I would give Transistor a final score of 8.9/10. This is a really great game and I highly recommend everyone experience it. It has an amazing soundtrack, beautiful artwork, fun combat and a fantastic story.

content:
, 2014
												Transistor is the second game from Supergiant Games, the creators of the critically acclaimed Bastion. It is an Action-RPG set in a futuristic sci-fi world full of dangers and mysteries. Transistor features a gorgeous hand-drawn art-style, a brilliant soundtrack and great voice-over as well as a deeply satisfying combat system. You play as Red who has been rendered mute at the beginning of the game and found herself in the possession of a mysteries sword that talks to her during the course of the game. While you uncover the secrets behind the sword and the mysteries of Cloudwalk City, you battle tons of enemies in a mixture of real-time and turn-based combat. During a combat situation you can enter a turn-based mode which enables you to give Red specific commands which she will subsequently execute upon pushing the “activate” button. This will give you the upper hand in most situations as each individual enemy type requires its own strategy. However, after executing these commands, Red will remain vulnerable for a couple seconds and if she loses her health points during this period, she will lose one of her four abilities and continue the fight with less abilities and a higher difficulty until the next checkpoint. Therefore, you have to choose wisely how to tackle each encounter. The game features an extensive upgrade system with active and passive abilities which you can combine at will in order to match you preferable play style. Furthermore, you can apply specific limiters at any time which will make the game on the one hand more difficult, but on the other hand will give you a greater experience reward. There is not much negative to be said about the game, however, some might criticize the fact that there is no equipment in the game at all. Furthermore, the story can be a bit confusing at times and while each enemy requires a specific approach, there are not that many different enemy types. However, these are tiny issues which should not keep you from playing and enjoying this great game. Thumbs up! 9/10

I think most people will take at least six if not 7-8 hours.I really loved this game. content:
, 2014
												Supergiant Games has done it again.Transistor is an amazing experience in line with the developers previous game, Bastion. Story:Absolutely fantastic. You feel attached to the main character immediatly and the constant chatter of the Transistor deepens the experience to a whole new level. It isn't narrate in the vein that Bastion was, but in the fact that Transistor talks to you and makes comments as you go along. My only complaint in this section is that the game was short (about 5 hours). You'll be begging for more.Gameplay:Solid action RPG with a nice twist. The Turn() system is akin to the VATS system from Fallout where you pause time and can move and attack without much repercussion. The downside of this is if you use all of the meter, you have a cooldown where you can't attack and are vulnerable. Combat can be a little tough, as a lot of the enemies can deal some serious damage later on, so you have to be smart about your attacks.  As you level up you get to choose new skills, upgrade exsisting skills, and choose limiters. Limiters are akin to the Gods of Bastion, in which you can toggle them to increase the difficulty of the game.Music:Engrossing and enthralling. It sets such a mood in the game. Some serious talent here from the composer. Way better soundtrack than Bastion, and I thought Bastion was incredible already.Conclusion:While it is short, it is totally worth the admission price. It is a wonderful experience and I am looking forward for more games from the developers.

er 5, 2014
												A visually striking piece of storytelling that drives home the point that you can create a fantastic storyline even when your main character is mute.I'm honestly not sure where to start with Transistor, other than to say this is one of those games I'd recommend everyone play before they die. The story is simple to follow while being beautifully mysterious at the same time, easily warranting a second playthrough just to pick up on the things that you overlooked before. Even if you don't care for a backstory though, what's happening in the forefront is more than enough to keep you interested, all the way up to the climactic end.The main characters--Red, the Transistor, and the four Camerata--are all well-designed and, perhaps more importantly, well-developed individuals who each have a personality that will stick with you well after completing the game. They're characters with motives that seem crystal clear in the beginning, but as the story unravels, your entire perspective gets turned on it's head.Red, the protagonist, is a female singer who refuses to let anyone control her, including the player. She may be mute, but she shows that she still has a prominent voice, despite the circumstances. The Transistor, Red's companion, is a cautious, loving individual that wants nothing more than Red's safety. He wants to protect her, but he's unable to in his immobile state. The Camerata, the villains of the game, is an organization that unleashes a malicious "virus" on the city known as the Process, slowly wiping out the entire civilization of Cloudbank. Uncovering the true motivations behind each of these characters is an exciting and surprising part of the narrative. It's hard to gush about this game without completely spoiling my favorite parts, so I'll stop my speech there.Besides the story, there are a few final things that really sold me on this game. First of all, the art direction of Transistor is absolutely stunning. Many times while playing I found myself doubling back just to appreciate the vistas a little longer. Honestly, I wish they'd release an art book, because I'd buy that in a heartbeat. On top of that, if you're familiar at all with Supergiant or Darren Korb, then you know how incredible this game's music will be. This soundtrack, along with the one from Bastion (Supergiant's previous game), are must-buys.Finally, if all of that isn't enough to convince you, the game has Logan Cunningham. And you can never go wrong there.

												Transistor isn't just one of those games that you buy, play, and then forget you ever owned. It's something that sticks with you for a long time, and that I believe defines who you are as a video game consumer, for lack of an equally dignified term. A stellar soundtrack, a plot not to be taken at face value, and combat with nearly limitless potential sees to this. I probably spent over an hour in total sitting and listening to Red hum to the music. This is a soundtrack so good that often times I hesitated to proceed to the next area, fearing that the track would change. As well as all this, the voice acting is very appealing to listen to, and much of the plot is revealed through dialogue (or monologue, rather), which keeps things interesting and attatches more emotion to it all. I struggle to think of any aspect of this game that isn't simply exceptional. The art style is somewhat simplistic, but only in the best of ways, and catches the eye. The environments create a sense of a much larger and quite fascinating world that you want to explore and lose yourself in.If nothing else has effectively captured your attention, I would also like to add that I sold literally every trading card in my possession so I could buy enough Transistor cards to craft the badge all three times.Please, do yourself a favor and play this game. Experience this. You won't regret it.

												ProsNice graphics and music. Awesome voice acting . Nice "artwork" and "feeling" during the gameCreative and interesting skills systemFun and moderately challenging combatNice atmospere and good storyNo grindingCons Short playtimeNo multiple save slotsNo "Sand box"No difficulty setting I would recommend the game to those who appreciate the good music and and nice graphics.The voice acting was well excuted and personally it was one of the best voice I heard in general , really soothing and deep voice. The atmospere of the game was also nice. These things made me engaged in game. However, I dont like the lenght of the game (1 story mode play would take Probably 3 - 6 hours for the most users) and sometimes I just lost where to go because basically no maps available. And too many "discarding" thing.What I meant the"discarding" thing is that - basically you choose one of the things that you can get when you lev up.It can be skill A , skill B and more MEM or more skill upgrade slots something like that and you choose 1 of these choices.This is very fine and I really like the choice in the game. However , I found later that the choice is permanent and theres no "Skill respec" until the end , and no turning back even in "new game+". So basically , I missed almost half of the skills / choices and there was no way to just "have fun" with the skills I missed on sandbox or something . If they had one , I coudnt find it.(Edited later : I found that after after leveling up several times more, I do get the all the skills. so this is not true. No scratch from beginning option though)Speaking of skills and lev up stuff, the skill system is but quite interesting. It is really fun expermenting with these stuff. One "element" can be active skill and can be fuction as the passive skill and even upgrade other skills. It makes A LOT OF the skill set possible. It gives you a lot of choices, makes you think a lot , and makes you creative. And at least for the "elements" you have, you can change anytime you want on the check point (But no discarded elements) The combat can be played both real-time and "turn based" but i think the game meant to be played on turn based. But If you are real quick with the mircro and the planning stuff , I think you may be able to play on real time only. The problem about the combat thing is that there's no "hard and easy mode" on the game so you are stuck with the "normal" . Otherwise, the combat was fun and pretty nice. Slightly lack of diversity of the enemy but I would say good enough.7.5/10Overall , the game is quite memorable one , and it has some issues but most people would appreciate the game.Don't buy the game if you are looking for huge amount of playtime of the game.

												Transistor might just be one of my favourite games these past 10 years. I can't remember the last time a game kept me playing for 10-12 hours straight. 												Short but sweet. Transistor is an isometric action RPG with beautiful art design, an addictive and unique combat system with loads of customisation and an intriguing storyline that requires some actual thinking on the player's part to fully understand. It also has one of the best soundtracks I've ever heard in a video game. The whole concept would be truly unique if not for Supergiant Games' previous title Bastion, and fans of that game will no doubt feel right at home with Transistor. It is a fairly short game, taking about 7-10 hours to complete, but it's a truly enjoyable experience throughout and definitely worth the asking price. The controls are very well optimised for both kb+m and a controller. Graphical options are pretty much non-existent, but the game looks absolutely gorgeous and should run just fine even on older PC's.

												This game is beautiful in so many ways, each of which is reason enough to play.The music is haunting and lovely, and the singer did a fantastic job capturing the character. The cyberpunk / art nouveau aesthetic works surprisingly well, and makes each new area gorgeous and memorable. The voice acting is evocative, drawing at the heartstrings in just the right way. And the plot is elegant and compelling, with the characters making reasonable decisions, trying to fix what's been done, but each solution makes the situation worse.The gameplay is similar to its predecessor, Bastion, but it adds a turn-based-strategy angle to the fighting. So instead of running around simply wailing on stuff, this time you get to plan out your moves. The game also deals with player death in a genius way; when you die, you get respawned but with one of your fighting moves broken (but you get it back a few fights later). The way it acknowledges player death, makes it meaningful, and forces the player to try new playstyles is devious and amazing.The feeling I came away with after playing (twice, for all the cheevos) was melancholy. It's sad, but the good kind, you know? The kind of sad you feel good for having experienced.That's what this game is. An experience - and a good one at that.

												I have a hard time explaining how deeply in love I am with this game. It's a masterpiece.(Spoiler Free)The first thing that hits you is the world, and the art, and throughout my entire thirteen hours (on my first playthrough) the environments never get stale or old. Everything is gorgeous and feels handpainted.The story and the characters are incredible and deeply engaging, but I won't say anything more than that all the voice actors involved are phenomenal.Battles are fun, fluid, and tactical. The mixture between the strategy and turn-based combat and something more real-time never gets old. Bastion this is not, Transistor is more methodical, and much slower. You're allowed to take your time to plan out what you'd like to do and put it into action. The skills and abilities system keeps the variety up. Usually I'd find my niche and stick to what I liked, but Transistor had me switching up my abilities at every single checkpoint, and not just for all of the files that I was addicted to collecting to get every single tidbit I could out of the writing.This noir wouldn't be complete without the jazzy cyberpunk soundtrack, which I could listen to forever and never get bored of. Not only is it good on it's own, but it sinks itself deep into the game and plays dynamically and reactively depending on what is happening at the moment.But, above all else, what makes Transistor a masterpiece is the atmosphere. The absolute dedication the game has to it's world and how much it sucks you in at every opportunity. Optional environments and points of interest litter every single map just to get another line or two out of the Voice. The way the music works itself in, the way enemies interact with you and all your abilities, the way the environments twist and change, the terminals you find, the files you can read, and the small interactions and character moments out of Red herself are unlike anything I have ever played before. If I were making a "Videogames as art" list, this would top it off.I will never forget this game.

												Okay, where do I begin...Overall, yes, I would recommend it, just because Supergiant made a unique experience with a definitive art style.That being said, the game to me is very flawed, especially when you compare it to its spiritual predecessor, Bastion:1) This game is incredibly short. You can beat it in 3 hours, if not less. There is a time and place for games as short as this (Journey, where replays are encouraged). 2) You spend half the game going through a few maps, get to a certain area, and lo and behold your final destination was JUST PAST where you started the game in the opposite direction. You spend the second half retracing your steps through a disfigured Cloudbank 3) Combat and customization are very limited. Combining your abilities in new, unique ways was actually rather satisfying, especially when you discover a new combination to trounce enemies ahead of you. Other than that, there is almost no character progression other than increasing your RAM (literally) and junctioning moves together.4) There were two voices (if you don't count Red's occasional humming), and I didn't feel an emotional connection to either of them because of how they were voiced. It was as if they took a page out of William Shatner's book of acting on pausing mid-sentence, coupled with very monotonous expressions. 5) Biggest complaint about the story though has to be how disconnected I was to all of it. I will say that the ending was well done, though. I can see the rationale behind it. 6) There was almost no tutorial to speak of. I had to figure out almost everything by myself. Any tutorial that was there was hidden behind technical lingo resembling computer code, which I suppose fits the game's style.6/10. Support your indie devs!

content:

												This game is unique.The art, music, story and voice acting are all fantastic, and a lot of people talk about it a lot, so I'm going to go straight to the gameplay, because to me, that's what really makes this game stand out.The gameplay in transistor is an interesting and deep blend of strategy, tactics, and action RPG. It looks like an action RPG - one character, running around the game world in real time, trying to pull off attack combos. And you can play it like that, if you get good at the controls. But you can also stop time and program perfectly timed combos to occur.That alone sets this game apart. The balance between those two completely different mechanics - using your moves in real time, and planning out moves in a safe, stopped, environment - straddles two completely different genres, and thus two completely different play styles. Besides the real time action RPG style of gameplay, you can more or less impose a turn based style of game play - the mechanic for stopping time is even called /turn. On your /turn, you try to deal as much damage as possible to your opponents by planning out the right moves in the right order so that they don't get blocked or cancelled. Then, you can just run around the board, dodging attacks until the meter reloads and you can take your /turn again.Obviously, most of the time, you find yourself doing a bit of both. You figure out good move combinations to use in /turn, and then while turn is loading, you try to use those same combos in real time to deal more damage. Sometimes, you find yourself using Turn primarily to dodge or reposition yourself, and doing all your real damage in real time. You find the middle ground that best suits you.But the real complexity and beauty comes in the wealth of moves available. You end up learning a bunch of different moves, and the moves can be adapted to three forms - they can be moves, they can modify other moves, or they can modify your player character. You like explosions, but the explosion move is too slow for your playstyle? Slap it onto one of your faster attacks to give it an extra punch. Or, slap your fastest attack on it, to remove its drawbacks. The combinations and complexity available is staggering, and it makes the game more personal and more fun. When you discover a great synnergy between two moves, that was your discovery, and you can feel proud of it.All of this makes the death mechanic in the game hit even harder. You have a health bar in this game, but when it gets to zero, you lose one of your moves - usually the one that's been most modified, so probably your best move. If you built your playstyle around one synnergy, you effectively have one life. If you have a lot of moves, you live longer, but each hit still really hurts, as it takes away one of your tools, and probably one you designed a little yourself and are proud of. This makes the 'death' of your moves matter to you, and makes the tension of the game more real.Since you can only reinstall moves at a save point, and your ''dead' moves will be unavailable for the next new save point you find, this also changes how you use your save points. In an insane reversal of usual game logic, you might choose not to use the save point that's right in front of a hard battle or a boss, so that you can go to it after the battle, restock, and get back your main moves more quickly. All of this is to say, there isn't another game fully like Transistor. It has elements from several different genres, and playstyles or strategies that you have from those other games might apply to it. But as a whole, this game is a unique experience, and one that is unque all the way down its considerable depths.It's also a very fun, immersive, and beautiful experience, and it can be extremely challenging if that's what you want, but also extremely casual if that's not.

												It took a while for Transistor to really hook me (about 2/3 of the way through my first playthrough), but at that point I went from mildly disappointed (I really loved Supergiant's previous game, Bastion), to entirely satisfied.  I think the reason for all this is that the combat system is really quite deep, and it took a lot of experimentation before I really started understanding the potential there.  I'm playing it through a second time now and really enjoying it.Aside from the mechanics, the game is beautiful and the soundtrack is excellent.  The story is really intriguing and told in a very minimal way.   A lot of it is told through short voice clips, but if you want to learn more about what is happening, you can also get snipets of story through interacting with the environment, from experimenting with the combat system or from reading message boards :)  Even the way the soundtrack is done complements the story.  I didn't play Bastion on new game+ because I felt like I experienced the whole thing and was satisfied at the end.  I think Transistor essentially requires a second playthrough because there's so much subtle detail packed in that you are bound to miss a lot of it the first time through.  Transistor is a really excellent game, but it is especially rewarding if you are willing to put some effort in.

												Transistor is a top-down, turn-based adventure game that takes place in a utopian society. The gameplay is very different from Bastion; in this game, all attacks are planned beforehand during each turn. This game is beautiful to look at and holds a beautiful story within.Pros:+From the music, to the voice acting, to the writing, to the art, this game is beautifully executed. I like the gameplay, but this is definitely a game you buy for the music, story and artwork.+The romance in this game felt genuine and believable to me.+The gameplay is entertaining; different "functions" (attacks) can be combined in a multitude of combinations, and there are multiple ways to win each battle.+Like Bastion, there is a new game plus mode where you can restart the game at a higher difficulty and continue levelling.+For those who like the battles, there are bonus challenges, similar to Bastion.Cons:-While planning your turn, you can't pan the screen to look at far away enemies. This is a minimal problem, as you can usually see far enough anyways, and you can also simply walk where you want to see and then cancel the move.This game took me ten hours to complete, but my girlfriend completed it in four hours, which I find amazing. I think most people will take at least six if not 7-8 hours.I really loved this game. While they don't have the big budget of a AAA company, Supergiant has managed to craft something that is both more unique and more impressive than most AAA games.

												Roblins Review:Transistor is a surreal and beautiful Sci-fi, Cyberpunk game with a great story, and has a soundtrack that might make your ears try to jump off your head and try to get into the game.~ The Combat is innovative in the fact that you can choose to use a turn based approach or take a direct approach (Although turns are a safer and more efficient way through the game). That along with the many play style options for combat. You can choose to be a tank, or use buffs to weaken your enemies. The game has a way of making you feel very powerful without it being too easy, and if it is too easy you can use Limiters to make the game even harder.~The Story is good, but you're left to figure out most of it yourself, which is something i like, but not everyone will agree on that. You play as a popular singer named Red, and you've just barely escaped death at the hands of the Camerata. A secret-ish Society in cloudbank (the city the game takes place in.) I don't want to say too much about the story. If you want to get every last detail on the characters you can use your combat functions in different ways to gain access to personal files. I liked this feature because it pushes you to try different play styles.~The Soundtrack is Visceral and well done. Most of the songs relating to the story so there is a deep sense of drive and emotion in every note. If you're into techno or anything of that sort you should love it.~The Art in this game is self explanatory. It's just amazing. The world of Cloudbank feels deep like it was once a bustling city full of people. Plus it has the best Flat bread Delivery around. It has a very Cyber-punk feel to it. It's just great.Overall I'd say this is the best game I've played in 2014. It has decent replayability as well. Only thing i have to complain about is that it was too short, and the only reason i say that is because i wanted more!  I highly recommend it. Amazing 9/10.

												TL;DR: Transistor is a good game, and it will make you feel good.Transistor is a narrative-driven turn-based game that always seemed to be reminding me of the Tron universe. It's in the middle of an apocalypse, yet it has an eerie peacefulness about it. As you go about the world and destroy the monsters that are transforming the world, you can't help but take a step back and listen to the protaganist Red hum along to the background music, or look out over a pier for a few seconds and think about the history of a town you never knew. Something about this game calms you down. All of the mechanics seem to cater to a casual playstyle, although some moments can be very intense. Even the fast and reflexive combat system seems to be designed to make you breathe. You can take as much time as you want to plan out your moves, take a breather, take a break from the loud fighting music and explosions that are happening around you. It's calming.Of course, there's the narrator. The more I play games with great narrators like The Stanley Parable or Bastion (the latter of which was the same creator of Transistor). The narrator of Transistor is more personal than the two, though. It addresses the character, not the player. You are simply an observer to this story, and the narrator is unaware of your existence. This game is between Red and her love. You are granted the gift of watching. It's very touching and emotional at some points to realize that this story has to end somehow, and the few moments where the narrator leaves you feel so void and wrong. I'm not really sure what to say about the narration in this game, other than it's not really narration at all. There's just only one character with dialogue.As I said, everything in this game seems to be designed to make you feel calm and content. As evil and chaotic as some parts of this game are, all of it makes you feel reflective, nostalgiac almost. It's a good feeling. This game will make you feel good. It's a pity that I can't think of eloquent enough words to describe this game. Maybe it's because there's a woman screaming nonsense in the other room and I can't process thoughts (sorry if parts of this review don't make sense, but I honestly can't hear myself think), but I think mostly it's because when you find something that is truly beautiful, it doesn't take well to words, and although I wouldn't say this game is pure beauty and art, it is beautiful, and it is deliberate in its design. That's all I ask from a game.

												Transistor.I honestly can't tell which one, Bastion or Transistor were more to my liking. Both have their awesome unique mechanics and stunning music.When you start the game, you don't have a main menu, instead you are put right into the game. This really took my by surprise. I think you'll understand what I mean once you launch the game.So, lets get on with it.The Plot: 10/10Just like in Bastion, you are thrown right into the game without any introduction. Just a gal with a sword-like object which apparently talks. First I had no idea what was talking to me. The further you go into the story, the more is revealed, along with the backstory of Red (the main character, the musician). Soon it appears that 4 villans, the Camerata, those who basically own the city Cloudbank. Not only that, they are mostly scientists who care for the city, but made a mistake, and... well, you'll find out.Gameplay: 9/10Bastion had a right-left-midbutton gameplay, while here you get abilities that you use. Not only that, it is also followed with Turn() feature, a planning feature that allows you to stop time and make actions like walking and using abilities for the price of Turn() potential (lets call it that). For instance, a Breach() ability (your very first ability you have access to) uses 20 Turn().Not only that, you get some introduction to different characters who these abilities belonged to. For example, Red's ability is Breach(), an ability that stuns the target and makes it more vulnerable for 1.6 secs. Another one was a racer, when you used the transistor to "absorb" his essence, you retrieved an ability that allows you to blink. Furthermore, you can read info on these abilities that reveal about the character.Each ability can also be used as a passive or an upgrade to a different abilities. They can be swapped at any time when you get to an access point.And of course, remember the Shrine in Bastion? Here you have so called "Limiters", they work exactly the same as those things in the Shrine, except they also reveal info on the "Process" if used.Music: 10/10I won't comment on this. No point.Visuals: 10/10Seriously, the visuals are just amazing. Some may complain tho, that they don't like cyberpunk stuff, but to me, the art in this is majestic. The lights, the sketches, everything deserves a 10 in my opinion.Duration: 7/10Sadly, its rather short, but if you play with limiters you may get a longer enjoyment from this. That's exactly what I did with Bastion. Yet Transistor is still shorter than Bastion. I really wish it either had a continuation or just a longer gameplay. That may ruin the plot however.Replayable? Yes, definitely. Its worth replaying. Unlike Bastion, you don't have to grind here to get levels (because you can't, lol).Overall:I really want to give it 10/10, but I can't. I honestly just can't. I want it to be a bit longer, I want to get more enjoyment, maybe have a reality where Process comes from, where I can destroy its core, where I can have some sort of a choice like in Half-Life at the very end, or... I don't know. I just feel the urge for this to be longer.So any way.9/10, I can't wait for Supergiant games to release a new game. Maybe soon, maybe later, maybe next year (I actually heard they are working on a new game to be released in 2017).TL;DR Transistor is awesome, has great music, gameplay mechanics and great plot. If you feel like you need a game that would allow you to relax and feel some enjoyment, then this is it. I am a Dota 2 player myself, and nothing relaxed me more than Bastion and Transistor (especially transistor, tbh). Go buy it.

												A beautifully crafted game with amazing visuals and a wonderfully composed music score. It is a game where you should definitely take your time playing, just taking in the scenery and appreciating the beauty of it. Just the visuals and the music were enough to fill me with a broad range of emotions and made me appreciate this game even more.The combat system is both pretty simple and complex at the same time. It's simple with the fact that it is a combination of real time and turn based combat system. You can pick one or the other. What is complex is that you have to learn the combat system by yourself as there are no tutorials to help ease you into this unique combat system. While it is fluid, I did feel as if this combat system was button-mashy, where i would plan my moves, execute the same combo over and over, and then mash buttons to dodge enemies while I wait for my planning ability to be ready again. There are limiters to make the combat in this game into a very difficult challenge, which I did enjoy.The story is powerful, and able to invoke many emotions in you. But when you think about the story critically, you find that there are many holes in the story and the story is not cohesively held together. I also felt like they kept the story extremely vague and I wish they could have fleshed out the story even more. Just get this game. The artwork and music more than justifies the price of this game.

												Personal Evaluation: My favorite "Za Warudo" power fantasy since F.E.A.R., SUPERHOT, and SSBB.The Objective: This third-person game is a mix of real-time and turn-based tactical action using a move selection and modification system that allows for many different play styles.  Functions, which can function as moves, mods, or passive buffs to the player, are aqcuired in the first story run and by leveling.  Applying these requires "memory", which you can also eventually expand by leveling.  Functions vary in utility from mobility to buffs and debuffs to damaging attacks and have various tactical effects depending on how they are applied.Executing moves outside of Turn(), the time-stopped mode where enemies are frozen to allow you to plan out a set of attacks, can be time-consuming in comparison to the Turn()-based execution unless the appropriate mod is applied.  In Turn(), your planning potential is aided by a flexible and calculated system where you can erase your moves to select a different one and see how much damage your actions are expected to incur on the enemy (emphasis on "expected", as some enemies can turn or teleport from backstab attempts that amplify damage).Similar to its predecessor, Bastion, the game features isometric elements, a "sandbox" where you can enter challenge doors or listen to the game's soundtrack (unlocked by completing challenges), and "recursive" gameplay (i.e. a New Game+ mode).  Unlike its predecessor, Transistor employs a death machanic that raises stakes without immediately ending a run.  Losing your entire health bar will disable one of your active functions (and, while not disabling them too, uninstall any mods applied to it), reducing tactical options for the round.  The function is recovered after getting through an additional round of enemies once your current round is resolved, and in the meantime, you are able to equip a new function in place of what was lost.  Losing all functions in a single round, while I have not experienced it, presumably results in necessarily restarting the round.  Retrying a round is also possible from the menu screen upon pressing Esc or your controller equivalent.The Subjective: I enjoy the mix of thinking on my feet to reach my Turn() with minimal health loss and planning out insane combos of moves in time-stop.  While it didn't happen often in the main story, losing functions got me to improvise, engaging me further in strategy and tactical consideration.  It is in the New Game+ Performance challenges that this need to improvise and find ways to reach Turn() without dying is magnified, as you gradually get access to functions and memory from a significant limitation, but losing them results in their complete disappearance; I found this challenge mode in particular to be the most difficult, but also the most informative with regards to how the functions can operate together.While you may desire to stick to some basic combinations, the game's challenge modes will present you with a variety of possible movesets that will work to great effect.  For me, it was a thrill to home in on my own hand-crafted deadly set of fuctions for the really stubborn enemies, but, even if I were to lose all but one of them, I still know several other options that will fit into place once I reach an access point to apply new functions.The story is pretty damn melancholic in its overall scope.  The destruction of the city at the hands of the enemy you encounter is not unlike what you see in Bastion, except that instead of the world having fallen apart, it is being remade to an unfamiliar and uninhabitable form.  The aeshetic of the established society reminds me much of the 1920 in the US, and its collapse, perhaps not coincidentally, seems to me to reflect how that prosperous decade would end... but that's just interpretation.Parting Words: I love being mean.

content:
, 2014
Full disclosure:This review was written pretty much hot off the presses of finishing the game, and as such everything below is expressive of my raw impressions of the game after completion. Let that say what it will of the quality of my review.--------------------------------------------Supergiant Games has hit the ball out of the park yet again with their second game. As I've made apparent, I liked Bastion, but this game is substantially different from Bastion in many ways. So if you didn't like Bastion (I hope you at least liked the music and narration), don't let that put you off of Transistor. How is Transistor different from Bastion, you might ask? The combat is entirely different, replacing a weapon-based combat system with an ability-based system with impressive depth. As you proceed through the game, you gain new abilities either through leveling up or encountering certain points, and each of these abilities is equipped in one of four slots (1-4 are their hotkeys). However, each of these slots has one open subslot and an additional unlockable subslot, and beside the four base slots, are two slots on each side that are passive slots. As I said, very impressive depth, because each ability operates differently based on whether it's equipped primarily (in the four slots), complementarily (in one of the eight subslots), or supplementarily (in one of four passive slots). The world is likewise in its differences. You're no longer in a fantasy-esque setting in Transistor, and you don't have to worry about falling off floating platforms anymore. You're grounded, but in a world as far out there as Bastion's. It's a fascinating modern, sci-fi styled world full of mysteries to try to grapple with, not unlike Bastion. Yet, these mysteries aren't resolved like Bastion's, not laid out for you by anyone. If you want to understand Cloudbank, you're gonna have to get digging for yourself. Fortunately, you'll probably want to after exploring the place and its characters.The cast is as dynamic as Bastion's, if not more so. There's more detailed background on the much larger casting this time around, and there's more chatter occurring. This isn't to say you're frequently stopped for conversations and the like, you're definitely not, and all the background is entirely optional to look into. You can play the game ignoring the characters as much as you like, and still enjoy it as much as if you were to pay attention, much as in Supergiant's previous title.The music is as vibrant as ever in this game. It's also as vital to the atmosphere as in Bastion, and while there are equally energetic tracks in Transistor's soundtrack as in Bastion, it's of a very different styling. It's softer, of an electronic jazz vibe, compared to some of Bastion's harder, folksy tunes. If you didn't enjoy Bastion's soundtrack, don't worry, Darren Korb has outdone himself in making Transistor's soundtrack distinct from Bastion's, something you can't necessarily say for many musicians.The story is fantastic...If you don't mind a story that won't hold your hand. The plot will keep you moving forward to figure out what happened to Red, as well as who acted against her and why, but perhaps even more compelling than that is understanding the world she lives in. Every part of the story from the characters to the setting to what led up to your adventure is a mystery for you to solve, and personally, I loved that. Even after having finished the game, I have questions, and I doubt there are answers, but I like being left with room to imagine on top of their world.If you don't like that, you may not enjoy it, but there's so much more to the game than that to enjoy if you can look past your discomfort with it. The gameplay and music and art are all lovely to experience and behold.The artwork is of a different stripe than Bastion's. It's a mixture of darkness and brightness, in a bit of contrast to Bastion's primarily bright, varied color palette. Transistor has a harsher, darker color scheme, seemingly set mostly at night, but is broken up by bright lights throughout and a transition into a lighter color scheme as the game proceeds. This isn't dark grays accompanied by muddy browns as seen in other games by any stretch of the imagination, but it is something of a darker color scheme if you're coming from Bastion. Not to mention it's also in an urban setting with more futuristic and interestingly styled buildings. That also serves to differentiate the artwork drastically in its own right, having you ascending stairs along the edge of towering structures and taking elevators here and there amidst buildings serves as a different experience than Bastion would have you expecting.Conclusion: If you're looking for a unique scifi styled game with a complex cast of characters with splendid voice acting, music, gameplay,  and artwork, you can't find much better than Transistor right now. Frankly, if you have to decide between this and Watch Dogs, coming out tomorrow as of this writing, I'd say save your money and buy this. While I have nothing against Watch Dogs and intend to get it myself, I think you'll find a far more compelling experience in Transistor, in essentially every way.Thanks for reading! I hope this helped inform you of the game, and led you to pick it up. It's absolutely worth it.

												I have a hard time explaining how deeply in love I am with this game. It's a masterpiece.(Spoiler Free)The first thing that hits you is the world, and the art, and throughout my entire thirteen hours (on my first playthrough) the environments never get stale or old. Everything is gorgeous and feels handpainted.The story and the characters are incredible and deeply engaging, but I won't say anything more than that all the voice actors involved are phenomenal.Battles are fun, fluid, and tactical. The mixture between the strategy and turn-based combat and something more real-time never gets old. Bastion this is not, Transistor is more methodical, and much slower. You're allowed to take your time to plan out what you'd like to do and put it into action. The skills and abilities system keeps the variety up. Usually I'd find my niche and stick to what I liked, but Transistor had me switching up my abilities at every single checkpoint, and not just for all of the files that I was addicted to collecting to get every single tidbit I could out of the writing.This noir wouldn't be complete without the jazzy cyberpunk soundtrack, which I could listen to forever and never get bored of. Not only is it good on it's own, but it sinks itself deep into the game and plays dynamically and reactively depending on what is happening at the moment.But, above all else, what makes Transistor a masterpiece is the atmosphere. The absolute dedication the game has to it's world and how much it sucks you in at every opportunity. Optional environments and points of interest litter every single map just to get another line or two out of the Voice. The way the music works itself in, the way enemies interact with you and all your abilities, the way the environments twist and change, the terminals you find, the files you can read, and the small interactions and character moments out of Red herself are unlike anything I have ever played before. If I were making a "Videogames as art" list, this would top it off.I will never forget this game.

												Full disclosure: I got the game for free from the developers, as I am a fellow SF-based developer. I don't think that clouds my judgement, but you can decide for yourself.The combat is innovative and fun. It starts kind of slow, but once you start getting more and more functions and playing around with the various combinations, it becomes really satisfying. I enjoyed putting together new combos, both in upgrades and in execution order, to deal with the various enemy types. I also liked that the game takes away functions when you die once - this forced me to come up with even more new combos, which was still satisfying! I wanted to share my combos with my friends, such as my stun-cluster-dash. So cool.My only gripe with the combat is some of the enemies rely on being super-fast to get at you. This can get pretty annoying, especially when you don't have the dash function available. So, keep that dash handy.I enjoyed the story and atmosphere quite a bit, but I can understand that many would find it pretty vague and unsatisfying. It's never quite clear why things start out the way they did, and I guess some would be bothered by that. Whatever - I enjoy David Lynch movies, so I'm totally AOK with stories that are more about tone than concrete plot. And the tone is quite amazing in this game. The art, music, and dialog establish a juicy sci-fi-noir vibe that is a pleasure to indulge in.Overall, it starts out a bit slow, but it hooked me soon enough. And I can't wait to play it again in Recursion mode. I beat it once in under 4 hours, so it's a bit on the short side, but for $20 I think that's reasonable. Again, I didn't pay for the game myself, so I can't honestly say how I feel about its length. But I can say that the game doesn't drag itself out, which is important to me as a consumer.

												Transistor is an amazingly fantastic game. It keeps you fully engaged with a fresh, original story and unforgettable characters. It doesn't waste any time, immediately throwing you into the shoes of a young woman standing over a dead man's body. As if that wasn't disorienting enough, the sword that has been driven through the man's body starts talking. And it seems to be talking to you. You progress through one of the most beautiful worlds I have ever seen in a video game. It strays from the typical monotone, corporate indifference of most technologically futuristic worlds by imbuing every building and streetlamp with color and personailty. The intoxicating setting combined with the incredible soundtrack make for an invigorating experience. You can even take a break from fighting to allow Red, the main character, to hum along with the music.As you fight your way through the multitudes of unique enemies, you are given access to new attacks and methods of defense. But rather than just choosing your top four favorite attacks and sticking with them throughout the game, you get the opportunity to mix and match each attack to create your own original loadout. For example, you could mix a simple stun attack with a leeching effect in order to continuously deal damage to a stunned enemy, or you could use that same stun attack in combination with with an explosive effect, so that you could stun multiple enemies at a time. Your decisions will deeply effect your entire method of gameplay. But don't worry, no mixture is permanent. You can always go back and switch out certain attacks and create all new ones. If you plan on getting this game, keep your mind open. Transistor will force you to rethink your definition of a soul and what it means to be fully integrated into a society defined by technology. And remember, as you find yourself growing emotionally attached to a fictional sword, you're not alone. Though some people won't admit it, we've all been there.

												Transistor and Bastion are probably two of the best games I've played for a long time. The amount of work the devs have placed into both of them is absolutely gigantic, creating a game that is polished from back to front. I usually have some nitpicks in every game I play, but Transistor is definitely an exception. The graphics are truly magnificent to the eye. There's detail to every little thing in every level, keeping your eyes in constant appreciation of the artwork in the game. It doesn't get boring not even in the slightest. I think if I ever did buy a soundtrack in my life, it'd be Transistor's soundtrack. The music is incredibly elegant, adding extra feeling to the visuals of the game. These two coupled with the fascinating gameplay clash together into a wonderful mix of "this game is the best thing I've ever played" kind of game. The gameplay keeps you on board the game nonstop, never getting you unattached. There's tons of upgrades you can get, lots of synergies with those upgrades, and a whole variety of attacks you can do. Voice acting, just like Bastion, is still at its best in Transistor. It doesn't feel cringey, doesn't feel forced, it's fluent and the remarks they make throughout the game keep you hooked up. Difficulty is a big thing in this game. It starts off simple but when you start progressing, it gradually increases and increases, up to a point where some battles do feel like a true challenge. Just like in Bastion, you can boost up the challenge with certain mechanics that stump some of your abilities, but you get rewarded with extra XP. On sale this game is at $3.99. You'll be missing a masterpiece if you don't get it at this price. Game lasts more than 12 hours and is also highly replayable. I recommend you to get this game for once.

content:
9, 2014
												Bastion was a massive success for Super Giant Games. Most people have played it and numerous gamers own it on at least two different machines. With that in mind it would have been easy for the studio to release a sequel or spiritual successor to it. We’d all have played it, loved it, and raved about it. Transistor is not like Bastion.Starting in a beautifully depicted futuristic city scape you pull an electronic sword from a body and you’re on your way. No explanation is given and no background about the world or yourself is forthcoming. The player, like the character you control is thrown in, as if awakening from some strange dream and this gives a wonderful sense of mystery and discovery as you progress.From the outside this may look to share some similarities with Bastion. The perspective is the same and there is also a narrator of sorts, although he is talking to the female protagonist as you go. Right at the start you begin to think this is going to be another hack and slash but then about five minutes in it asks you to hit the freeze button and everything changes.Here, you suddenly realise you are actually in a real time/turn based cross over style RPG. You can execute attacks in real time (and even boost them to activate almost instantly), but the real trick is mastering the freeze system. Hitting the button stops everything and you then have an action bar you can use up before the enemy moves again. It’s kind of like the V.A.T.S system in Fallout 3 or the system at work in Vagrant Story.During this time you can move around and stack up attacks. Pressing the button again sends you into action like a blur across the screen. The downside is that you then can’t use any attacks or special moves until the bar has regenerated in full. The more attacks you use, the longer the bar takes to recharge. This means you have to be extremely careful about what you are doing as you are often slower than the enemy robots sent to stop you. It’s essential to get in, attack and get back out to a place you can safely recharge as avoiding damage otherwise is almost impossible and you’ll be downed in no time.If your health bar depletes while you have charge time you’ll get a chance to move away from danger. If not, one of your powers will be damaged and unusable until you make it to two save points. This severely limits your attacking options and often leads to a daisy chain effect of you losing all your powers and flat lining. On the off chance you are finding things too easy you can also add a number of handicaps as you go which increase difficulty and the amount of experience you gain.The options you have to play around with are numerous and can be set up in a ton of different ways. This is one of Transistors strengths but we can see it easily overwhelming some players. When you gain a power you can do one of three things with it. Equipping it in an active slot will allow the player to use it via a button press. This could be a long range attack, a fast dodge, an area effect attack or something like summoning a creature to assist you. All attacks have different speeds in real time combat and few of them work fast enough to run through the game hacking away without the freeze system. Each active power can also be boosted by equipping powers as support. For instance, you could take the bouncing bomb power and add it to your long range attack, thus making the attack ricochet off enemies and into others.  You can add two boosters to each active attack which opens up all sorts of crazy possibilities. Finally, you can add powers to your passive support slots. This means they normally do things like boost player speed or increase resistance. Any power can be assigned to any slot on any other power so finding the perfect combination will require some thought and the possibilities are just about endless. The only limit on what you can do is that each power takes up a certain number of points and once that hits maximum nothing else can be equipped.While you are getting used to the combat you’ll be experiencing some absolutely beautiful visuals. The Neo Noir tone of the game is offset by stunning, neon tinged environments full of small details and snippets of information about the world you’re exploring. It reminded us of an isometric Deus Ex or the SNES version of Shadowrun if the rundown world had been replaced with some kind of semi-utopian society. There are also a few pretty big nods to Final fantasy VII in there as well. It’s gorgeous and the musical score and sound effects also help to build a picture of a once perfect, now lonely world where something seems to have gone wrong very quickly.Overall, Transistor is a triumph of both style and design. It takes some getting used to and you’ll need a PC running comfortably above the minimum specs to get a smooth experience but Super Giant Games have tried something a little different here and it works. There’s the odd pacing issue and players will need to spend some time getting used to how the combat works but it’s a rich and rewarding experience and something that you’ll likely return to long in the future.Overall 9/10
