content:
er 28, 2014
OverviewTransistor is, the best way I can put it, an isometric, linear brawler with a heavy emphasis on story. It's much in the vein of Bastion, and, considering that the same company made Bastion, this is easy to see. One can skip this entire review by just realizing that if you enjoyed Bastion you would enjoy this; the narrator from Bastion even voices the Transistor.In the story, you play as Red, a well-known singer in the city of Cloudbank. You use a weapon, aptly named the Transistor, as the method of combat. The city is being overrun by a strange, robotic-seeming organism called the Process that overtake whatever they touch. In search of answers, the now-mute Red goes back into the city to search for answers (sound familiar?).The game is fought in real-time but also utilizes a unique combat system called Turn(). Essentially, time freezes and you have an opportunity to plan your moves. Every action you take reduces your opportunity to do additional attacks in Turn(), and when you execute it, you cannot attack (except if certain moves are upgraded) while it recharges.Around Cloudbank are two things: access stations and terminals. Terminals are optional and for additional insight into story, and access stations can be used to upgrade the Transistor and modify it. You have a set amount of "memory", and each different move takes up a certain amount. You can upgrade moves using other moves to give it different abilities, like area-of-affect or a temporary switch-sides mechanic. Finally, you can have passive effects. You start with 16 memory and can increase it as time goes on.But this review is getting lengthy, so I'll just cut it down a bit.ProsSimilar to Bastion, which is one of my favorite games of all timeSatisfying combatCaptivating storyEngrossing world that feels realConsCombat is limited by memoryGame is very short; only took four hours to finish on my first sitting (this is somewhat put off by the fact that I did no challenges)Gameplay does not match up to the standard that Bastion set (Transistor is considered Bastion's spiritual successor)No weapon variety; only the Transistor is usedUI can be hard to figure outEnemy mechanics must be learned, as they are not explained wellInconsistent difficulty; hard in some places, easy in othersDisappointing ending; though sentimental, it was lacking and felt rushedA bit too similar to Bastion; generic-named mute protagonist, same narrator, same style, and though it imitates Bastion it doesn't do so very wellSomewhat confusing story; in order to even understand it, I had to look up an external guideFinal VerdictTransistor is an okay game. Not as good as Bastion, but a good game. However, at $20, it simply isn't worth the price. If you want to buy Transistor, wait until it's on sale.I rate Transistor 6/10.

And the second seems to offer some more things to keep you entertained.I didn't find anything that this game does not do really good except for some user interface issues (mostly when installing functions, though you can drag&drop and stuff, it's just a bit strange when you change a whole lot).---------Please be aware though, there is one minor design flaw. In fact this may wipe your progress if you are not careful so please read on IF you want to play on maxed difficulty and change around your playstyle a lot:After reaching the top of the tower DO NOT LEAVE unless you have a foolproof ability kit or turned off all/some limiters. The game saves after a cut-scene and you will have to fight a high tier dog and some minions. YOU DO NOT GET THE OPTION TO CHANGE YOUR BUILD EVEN IF YOU LOAD. You can pretty much always beat anything before even with a sub-par build and a few deaths but this encounter can be devastating with the wrong build. It took me several minutes of optimizing a test build that was not working as intended.---------Probably the only game where I used Tab for other things than minimizing the window. And I used it a lot. Definitely the only game where I didn't do anything else except holding the Tab key at times...Buy this if you have a working Tab key. If not, wait for a discount. Or don't, because it's incredible. Seriously, the only problem people are having with this game is that it is too short. Great games are always too short, or we wouldn't play the bad games anyway...Edit: 2nd playthroughThe design flaw as explained above is here more apparent and it happens more often, though you should have a good setup at this point anyway. being able to have multiples of the same function also makes stuff very interesting. Most encounters are very easy (with the correct kit) but some encounters seem to be randomized so you can have pretty challenging fights, even though I nearly instantly killed anything, I still only had about 20-30% life after most fights. The challenge rooms you get access to are okay (fighting against a last boss kind of type is forgettable though), the randomized fights can be a nightmare and the repeating "only fighting against an increasing number of men" is dumb and very unfair with the wrong abilities. This changes in the later rooms though and I had some pretty fun times going through the last 16 waves, losing my good abilities right at the start and only reaching my standard setup right at the last wave. So far a recursion seems unnecessary, the real meat (plot, style, music) is already inside your bellies, so the only thing left is to play around with the game mechanics. Those are excellent but you should know when to stop before you ruin your experience. See that mode as optional and not as required and you will be fine :)

												I don't review many games, but Transistor, much like SuperGiant's previous title, Bastion, exceeded my expectations on all fronts.This game is a tremendously soulful piece of work, and from the very start to the very end, is first and foremost a work of art. The music, narration, artistic style and presentation flow together in a way that I would probably say outclasses almost any other game i've played. Anyone with a quibble of curiousity and a penchant for great games, or even works of art, should immediately purchase Transistor (AND Bastion) and enjoy the ride.To touch on the gameplay itself, the combat is inventive and blends several previously done elements (pseudo-turn based combat, action queues, tactical-execution-based combat) into a pretty seamless and enjoyable experience. It is two parts arcade, one part strategic pause-and-think game. It remains fresh and has a lot of room for player creativity due to the openly configurable nature of abilities acquired throughout the game.What follows are some brief pros/cons:Pros:+Incredible Art. From music to artwork, this entire game is a masterpiece.+Gameplay. The combat remains fresh, enjoyable, and creative all the way through.+Difficulty.  Like bastion, difficulty is born of modifiers you can apply to enemies, which give you bonuses for being brave.+Storyline.  Again, this is a work of art and the storyline is rich, heartfelt, and incredibly immersive.+Soundtrack.  Incredible, as usual.Cons:-Length.   The game itself isn't that long, although there are excuses to re-play the game with new conditions and toy around with the combat some more.That's really all I can see anyone really griping about with this game.In total, I'd give Transistor a 9.5/10, as one of the most absolutely awesome pieces of work i've seen in terms of gaming. It isn't a triple-A 40 hour experience... but it's an incredibly rich, artistic romp through an engaging and incredibly envisioned city of Cloudbank.9.5/10-Colt

												Interesting story/setting.  Combat plays more like a puzzle, with the puzzle being as hard as you decide to make it using optional settings (limiters) you gain through the game.  Single playthrough took me 8 hours, but you get the option for a NG+ that also changes the dialogue you experience the second time through; which gives another perspective on the narrative.  As expected from Supergiant, the art and soundtrack are excellent.  The game at times can feel like walking through the work of Gustav Klimt.  The soundtrack is a largely ambient set of aucoutic guitars and subtle electronic puncutated by vocal hums.  The game also features a couple full tracks with lovely lyrics.The negatives for me were related to the amount of menu activity.  Pieces of backstory and character information are hidden in skills you use, and using the skills in different ways unlocks more of that information.  In order to change how your skills are arranged (to use them differently), you have to visit a menu and shuffle things around between most combat sequences.  It's not a big deal, but slows down the feel of progression and the pace of your play.  It feels tedius.  Granted, you could skip the unlocking of this information and stick to a skill arrangement your comfortable with.  Additionally, some skill arrangements work better for some fights than others, and you don't have any way to predict what the next fight will be, so you usually have to fail the combat sequence to go readjust for the fight.When you're out of the menu's and fighting, you do appreciate the maleability of the skills.  Using any single skill as either an active, augmenting, or passive ability and over a dozen skills, you can create what feels like an endlessly diverse series of offensive arrangments.  Really cool.Overall, a very positive experience.  Definitely worth the $19.99 price tag on release.

content:

												Transistor is a big and yet a small step from Bastion.There are certain things, which remain similar to it, but for the most part it's completely different.The themed music and fitting art style  is definitely the most similar to Bastion as they were done by the same people.So are the Function Upgradesystem in Transistor and the Item Upgradesystem in Bastion very similar, as both offer a lot of possibilities.There are also modifications to yourself or the enemies in Transistor, very similar to the Gods.But this is also where the similarities in those two games end, which is what most people don't see.Bastion is a Hack and Slash game, there much easier to jump in.Transistor is a "semi turn-based" RPG and I am putting it into qoutations for the simple reason, that Transistor needs to be played as a turn-based game AND a realtime game and even though it tries this very weird idea for gameplay, it works beautifully, once you fully grasped the idea of what you need to do.Transistor is not a game which will guide you at your hand. It very much wants you to learn almost everything on your own. It only tells you how to fight, how to use Turn(), how to upgrade and how to use limiters. So how a Upgrade actually affects a Function is for you to find out yourself.For example, once you use a Function during Turn(), it won't be active during the realtime section unless you have a certain upgrade on it, aside from a few certain functions. If you don't have any active Functions for the recharge phase of Turn(), you're not going to be able to do much and have to run away. If you only have active functions during your recharge phase, you can fight more, but you won't do a lot of damage. The goal is finding the sweet spot between those two, which the game itself provides more than enough practice for in the challenges.The overall story of the game is confusing, if you don't go and actively search for every little bit of extra information or fully unlock all bios, but if you do, you'll see how it all fits together. It's sadly only 5 hours long, if you do all that with a few limiters on and you won't get a full gameover either, at least I didn't experience one. Though I myself aren't to sure wether what I saw at the end of the game actually is the ending of the game, since it wants you to do a second playthrough.So to sum it up:Music: 5/5Art: 4/5, because pure white screens are annoying.Gameplay: 4/5, because it requires a lot of getting used to and experimention with abilities.Story: 3.5/5, because it makes sense, but only when you spend to time to unlock almost everything.Bastion vs Transistor: It's not comparable, since they are already gernes wise completely different games. So, people, please stop comparing these games. They, of course, do not play the same.

												Bastion is an easy and accurate point of comparison for Transistor; if you like one, you'll probably like the other. But the gameplay here is a lot deeper and richer, so it's worth a look even if you didn't care for Supergiant's previous effort.Similar to Bastion, the story is simple but beautifully presented. The futuristic/maybe-computerized city of Cloudbank is a visually lush setting for monster bashing, and the snippets you find and decipher throughout the game paint a unique portrait of the city's history and the villain's motivations. It's easy to get drawn in, even if, from a player's perspective, you're just running around murdering everything in your path.It probably helps that your rampaging is so enjoyable. Combat is real-time, but you can periodically freeze time to cue up a string of commands as if it were turn-based. That combined with the incredibly flexible system of combining your power-ups into increasingly elaborate attacks opens up a tremendous number of options, both on-the-fly and in terms of your overall playstyle. Want to kite around and chip away at range? You can spec for that. Want to play fully real-time as a bruiser? Sure. Want to mind control everyone into killing each other? Go for it. Run around unleashing monster turn-based combos whenever you can? Yessir.If anything, the biggest problem is that the mechanics are SO flexible that it gets daunting. Thankfully, there are a handful of mechanics that guide you towards new combinations (avoiding the Diablo 3 "here is a new option that you have no reason to care about" issue) and, like Bastion, the game's difficulty is rather forgiving but has options for you to increase it on the fly.But bottom line, this is beautiful, enjoyable, and distinct experience that doesn't overstay its welcome. Highly recommended.

												The system for combining and modifying attacks really makes this game special. By allowing the player to respec at every checkpoint, the game allows the player to experiment with this system, which is complex and nuanced enough to give satisfying rewards to experimentation. The best combination I've found so far is void() with purge() and crash() as an opening attack. Limiting the total slots available for attacks forces tradeoffs and compromises that make the process of building and rebuilding Red's skill set continually interesting.I've finished one playthrough in about 6 hours completing a fair number of the optional test levels. I'm looking forward to playing a new game with more skills unlocked to allow for more experimentation.The story is mysterious, but enough hints are provided to make it intriguing. The relationship between Red and the Transistor really carries the game, although it doesn't immediately develop.The ability to pause time is a nice inclusion because it allows for a slower, strategic playstyle. I used it for nearly every encounter. Waiting for the cooldown is a drag, but the game thoughtfully allows the player to make tradeoffs to mitigate the cooldown.Lastly, the music and art style are beautifully atmospheric, and I found the voice work solid.

content:
, 2014
												If ever you come across that common question of whether video games truly belong in the world of high art, along with the likes of time-immune paintings, masterpiece films and all-time hit singles, you only need to answer it with Transistor.To say that Transistor is a work of art is no exaggeration. The beautifully painted art style reminiscent of Supergiant Games' brilliant favourite, Bastion, go hand in hand with the lovely soundtrack by Darren Korb. Ashley Barrett lends her vocals to most of the soundtrack as the protagonist, Red's, singing voice while the gravelly voiced Logan Cunningham returns as Red's companion, a man stuck in a sword. Their story is one of hardship, as they fight a system off in the hopes of getting what was stolen from them back. This good story backs its visuals and audio to make it an attractive package.The drawback that most see in dedicating a game as art is the common mistake of letting the gameplay slide into abandon. Thankfully, Supergiant Games made sure that the game's mechanics is deep and enjoyful. The combat system is incredibly customizable and allows for versility. I was eager to try out as many combinations as possible to find one that suited my playstyle and I eventually found my favourite life-stealing spamming long shot laser that exploded upon contact. There is an alright amount of enemy variety, especially since enemies gain abilities as you progress through the story.In short, Transistor is not only brilliant to look at or listen to, its fun to play and has a story worth following. Sounds like the perfect package, right? Now, some have complained that the game is really short and not worth the full retail price. My first playthrough lasted 9 hours, since I took my time to explore both the wonderful science fiction world and the expansive combat options. One should know that the game comes with a New Game + option, known as Recursion where you retain your levels and combat options as you play through the story again. In this mode, the enemies are leveled according to yours to make this second playthrough a tough one. While this NG+ option is there to add to the game's worth, not many would want to play through a second round.I've been playing this for 15 hours so far and am halfway through my second playthrough, loving it all the same the second time. To me, this is a work of art, one I'll be recommending to many.

content:
7, 2014
												When a friend asked me what Transistor was like, I said it was like Bastion, but moreso.  Initially, I wasn't so certain as to whether or not this was fair to Supergiant's second game, but the more I thought about it and the more I played, the harder the patterns were to ignore, to the extent that it may even be called a design aesthetic.  To cover the traits shared by both...*  A stylized, eye-catching isometric world (Transistor specifically is Klimt and Mucha taking on cyberpunk)*  A well-promoted, atmospheric soundtrack with solid vocals*  A central hub to refine combat talents, listen to music, reminisce*  A somewhat unique combat system that heavily involves customization of weapons*  A means of tweaking difficulty by changing enemy behavior and PC limitations*  A plot that is concerned with the excesses of technology*  A bit of a political agenda (Bastion is about colonialism, Transistor, about individuality, dystopia, and the banality of a world that tries to please everyone by consensus)*  A thought-out, built up world supporting the story*  A strong, nearly intrusive narration*  A silent protagonist trudging through a landscapeWhere they share influences, they also share flaws.  Weapon customization isn't easily tailored to enemy groups (it's randomized in New Game+, it can't be) and some combos are game breakers.  My favorite setup, which was like tazing someone into quicksand and then golfing a live grenade into their gut, was to spam Void(Get + Purge), then Load() + Breach(Crash + Ping, aligned with both packet and enemy).  If I didn't get one-hit kills, it was only because I misaligned, and nothing late in the game was dangerous enough to get me to tweak my methods.The same combat system is just barely interesting and fun enough to sustain itself, considering how heavily the game relies on it.  The puzzle aspect of using Turn() seems particularly underutilized, since you only use it once perhaps ten minutes into the game and never again.  Even something as mundane as flipping off a few switches using Breach() or rapidly navigating around using Jaunt() or (let's not get too ambitious) a stealth sequence revolving around use of Mask() might add some dynamism to gameplay that is otherwise combat-dependent.The world is well-thought out and also empty.  The city or the immediate location is gestured to in context of a larger world, but the current environment is made to be the only relevant thing and the current environment only very rarely has NPCs to interact with.  Owing to the silent protag/narrator combo, this means that your interactions with the world are limited to the passive storytelling that is the narrator's exposition or your reading of a third-hand account.  Sybil, as the easiest example among the NPCs, has a duality and is complex because we are told that she has a duality and is complex.  We never see her as the cheery social butterfly, we just see her, briefly, as covetous to the point of violence.  In spite of this emphasis on telling over showing, certain details are poorly telegraphed by both games.  In the instance of Transistor, The Process can apparently turn people into The Process, at least once, but no one is surprised or confused by this when it happens.  It is taken as not worth mentioning.To Transistor's credit, it has resolved the matter of not initially having antagonists.  Transistor does have antagonists.  Sort of.  You know who they are at the beginning and you pursue them and fight them, though the reasons why are ultimately confused or dissatisfying in their results, much like they were in Bastion.  One can have dissatisfaction in storytelling, and I often love movies and TV series that end on bummer notes, but when you're controlling a character, pushing them against various odds to do the thing that their world needs them to do, stories that feel incomplete or under-resolved stand out more.  Adding to this, the New Game+ has less going for it now than it did in Bastion.  At least in Bastion, you could choose among ending options.  New Game+ in Transistor offers three things: the ability to continue leveling and get duplicate functions, slightly more populated combat settings (none difficult enough to turn off any of the limiters), and slight change in atmosphere as signaled by different posters and one altered bit of dialogue.  That's all.  Oh and you get your achievement.  Lovely.To summarize, Supergiant makes a particular game.  It's arty and appealing to the senses and has controls that establish a baseline level of enjoyment, but there's too much devoted to getting the baddies and since they aren't good at developing a plot or characters, corners are cut and they settle for an experience where they tell you most of what's going on.  In my opinion, a lot of effort that went into conceptually creating a distinctive world ends up going to waste because they're awful at storytelling.  But it's a reliable and somewhat unique type of game and gaming experience, and if you're into that, then Transistor could be a game for you, so long as you only play it the once.  It feels like an improvement on the Bastion model, but its strengths and shortcomings also feel more extreme in part due to fatigue resulting from being the same type of game.B-?

												I loved Bastion and I love this game even more.The narrative style is different but still present. The sound track is just as excellent as Bastion's if not more so. The art style is different but just as good. Everything you liked about Bastion is there and just as good, but different.Except the combat. The actual combat itself is brilliant and rewarding, with thousands of possible ability permutations and lacking the feeling that any one combination beats out the others. All the abilities are useful, all of them fun, and all of them let you tackle each fight in a variety of interesting ways.Some people have complained about the combat in this game, but their complaints are quite bluntly bewildering to me. While it does get increasingly challenging, and dying can be frustrating, I never had to redo any one fight more than twice, and the game autosaves often. I have not enjoyed a game this much in a very long time. It is exciting to even talk about. This is Game of the Year - or at the very least the Indie Game of the Year. For $20 you get around 9 hours of singleplayer content that is brilliantly designed, written, and narrated.For $10 you get a soundtrack that is around 1 hour, 9 minutes of excellent videogame soundtrack.In my opinion you do yourself a disservice not purchasing this game.

content:
er 13, 2014
Setting:You play as Red, a singer who lives in the art deco cyberpunk city of Cloudbank.Cloudbank is an apparent democratic utopia where the citizenry vote on everything. 'Everything' including things such as the weather, the colour of the sky and the daily layout of the city. Here is a city which is almost certainly a step sideways from our reality and into the virtual, much like The Matrix movie or the TV series Reboot. There are 'back doors', loopholes and hacks much like one might find in software. The game locations are named after coding terms, and the names of your abilities and the ubiquitous Process, your primary antagonist throughout the game are reminiscent of faulty or malicious programming. Then of course there's the name of the city itself: Cloudbank being reminiscent of something ephemeral and unreal, a distributed network of servers which may be real or virtual. The game opens with Red having survived an assassination attempt by four individuals who call themselves the Camerata, and her voice has been stolen.Red is kneeling next to a man impaled by The Transistor, the weapon that they attempted to kill her with, a blade reminiscent of a circuit board. The blade hums to life at her touch, and her not-exactly-deceased friend speaks to her from it. He’s character, narrator, and your only weapon of choice. However his memory is corrupted and with Red unable to speak the nature of their relationship is built up gradually over the course of the game. Red takes the Transistor and sets out looking for answers and vengeance against the Camerata as a mysterious force known as 'The Process' seeks to stop her and corrupt and unravel reality.Visual Aesthetic:Visually this game is a joy to behold, with a rich colour palette in a semi painterly style with an isometric viewpoint and a glorious attention to detail. Transistor is a digital world, a cyberpunk art deco utopia in collapse with a plot of vengeance running through it. This is like playing through painting, one that turns from contemplative and sombre to dynamic and sharp with the neon bright light show that combat brings to the fore. Holographic effects and stylised programming glitches also help sell the virtual reality you romp through. Music:The music and sound infuse a soul into Transistor which goes beyond a beautiful score. Much of the music is that of Red’s and, word of advice, pay close attention to the lyrics as they are more integral to the storyline than it may appear. This is especially true at pivotal moments where a track may ‘corrupt’ and alter, providing insight and subtext to a situation, or foreshadow coming events. Gameplay:As an ARPG, combat takes the lion’s share of gameplay as Red cuts a swath through the Process in her hunt for members of the Camerata.Each ability gained can be used 3 ways with the Transistor: an active attack, a modifier for active attacks or a passive ability that augments Red. You slowly gain information about the world by using abilities in each of these ways, giving you a new incentive to change up your build. This information helps paint a vibrant and culturally rich world – a fusion of 1920s art deco and democratic utopian cyberpunk gone wrong.The twist, is that Red is able to pause the flow of time and modify the world through abilities. Red can even later acquire super user access with glorious results. During ‘Turn time’, Red can queue up actions (movements, attacks and other abilities) with action points and then unleash them rapid-fire on your enemies.Movement is important in both modes of combat, so turns and real time are one part positioning, one part offense, and one part “NONONONO RUN RUN RUN.” One could sit still, but efficient movement and punching through the abstract high tech nightmare programming of the Process with planned out status effects and backstabbing will give you a significant upper hand. One could also play solely through real time, but you would miss out on the glorious satisfaction of watching Red execute your plan (and multiple unlucky foes) in a bullet time moment of neon samurai fury.Gameplay death is also handled in an interesting way. When your health bar drops to zero (and it will) you won’t die, rather an active ability will get burned out of the Transistor for a few checkpoints. Only once all active abilities are burned out do you start again from the last checkpoint. This temporary loss of an ability forces you to experiment and find new strategies and this helps keep the gameplay from stagnating. The combat is broken up with contemplative treks through this apparent utopia in collapse (apparent as even before the impending process wrought apocalypse there are indications that prejudice, inequality and a lack of personal agency were more present than Cloudbank’s citizenry would care to admit).  Here, the interactions between Transistor and Red really shine. Narrative:The relationship between Transistor and Red is the core of the game’s story and how they communicate is really what makes it – how Red expresses herself despite being mute is especially compelling. Body language involving the sword, clever use of message board terminals, split-second decisions she makes. Red is a complex, interesting character whose personality is drawn in assured and precise strokes. Quiet moments and sudden decisive actions reverberate with equal strength and land home with an intimate touch and the force of a sledge hammer respectively. She may have been a singer, but her response to tragedy is what outlines who she is. She is action and silent fury with burning purpose. The only thing left when the world and everyone else is long gone.Transistor provides a contrast to Red. A sword with the power to alter reality, a weapon of enormous power is one of the more subtly vulnerable characters I’ve come across, one that speaks fondly and protectively of Red, and tentatively speaks heartbroken confessions in dire situations. Having the narrator in the form of Transistor on board for the ride and his interactions with Red makes this very compelling and I think more intimate. His writing is excellent as is delivery of the voice acting. Transistor and Red really are a perfect match. A body and mind without a voice, and a mind and voice without a body.The overarching plot as well, is told in a very minimalist fashion and is deceptive in its depth. It is a larger world from a lore perspective than one might think. One which is subtly told and implied through character exchanges, terminals, and abilities. The latter is quite interesting, a good union of gameplay and narrative exposition, although the ability exposition can be a slog at times. as it is delivered via text.VerdictThe gameplay is near perfect the story compelling, and the presentation flawless. If I were to lay criticism at Transistor it would be a desire for more solid and defined chunks of lore, world building and narrative. The storyline can be completely incidental and missed if one does not seek it among the sublime ARPG romp. That said, I’m still thinking about world, the story, and its myriad meanings. It is an experience which has really stuck with me after the credits rolled. It is also one of the only games that I have felt I needed to play through again immediately after, to ‘Recurse’ as the game tantalisingly puts it.

												Absolutely brilliant. The soundtrack, story and characters(as few as there were) could have made a visual novel all on its own but Transistor tops it all off by having an amazing and permutable battle system. Not even counting the special Turn() based strategic battling, the sheer number of choices, combinations and OPTIONS you have to battle is insanely staggering.You can pick 4 actives, 2 upgrades per active, and 4 passive abilities. With a total of 16 different choices to slot into any of those. The numbers seem 'small' but doing a bit of math on this and I realize I can't properly account for all the situations and duplicate abilities you can also have later on. Not only that, but the order of the abilities even matters for some cases, amplifying or accidentally nullifying what you're trying to do.The amount of ways you can tailor your skills, number in the hundred thousands, if not the millions and that's not even including your own personal playstyle, timing and strategies. This is a game that rivals many others in sheer options of battle choices while maintaining a subtle yet engaging storyline. I can honestly say I felt this game was a true masterpiece, battle, story, art, soundtrack, replayability. God damn.

												Transistor... I love Bastion. It is one of my favourite games ever, one I keep pushing unto everyone I know, so when I hear of transistor I had to preorder it. Finally it came out and off I went. The game is a worthy successor. Bastion without being Bastion, familiar enough for nostalgia but different enough to escape repetition. The graphics are excellent and work very well with the game type, the soundtrack is absolutely amazing, everything in the sound clicks together, music, effects, narration. The action switches between two game modes giving you both frenetic pace and tactical stimulation. The story is also gripping, you quickly create a bond with the characters and get emotionally invested, knowing what happened to the city, why you, who are they. The only problem is when you answer all those questions and... that's it. The game feels short, leaves you a bit of a bitter after taste. Maybe because of how pleasurable the trip until the end is, and not so much by fault of its own. I guess that in that, it is not Bastion. Play it, enjoy it.

content:
15, 2014
												Transistor is the second game from Bastion developer Super Giant Games, and it is another exceptionally crafted artistic RPG.In Transistor you play the role of Red, a beautiful and talented musician who has seemingly lost her voice.  The game begins with Red pulling a sword like device known as the Transistor out of the chest of a dead man.  Immediately the Transistor begins talking to Red as if it knows her.  The voice of the Transistor is how we learn what's going on in this abandoned ghost town of a city called Cloudbank.   Much like the narrator in Bastion comments on the situation of Caelondia, the Transistor will talk to Red about things happening in Cloudbank.  It seems Super Giant Games really has a thing for mysterious apocalyptic events that wipe out flourishing cities.  Not only is the Transistor your talking guide through the game it's also a very powerful tool and weapon.   In the beginning the Transistor only has two functions loaded into it, thus giving you two different attack options.  As you level up you'll unlock   more functions, function upgrade slots, and passive function slots.  The function customization and use is incredibly deep and fun to experiment with as you explore combinations to fit your play style.  It really makes the combat an enjoyable sandbox of trial by fire.Every function in the game has 3 optional ways of using it in the Transistor.  The first use is an Active attack and used to directly afflict damage or other debuffs on the enemies.   The second use is an upgrade slot to an existing Active attack.  This will add extra abilities to your attacks.   The final use is a passive slot which will grant you various buffs or abilities that are always active.  With 16 different functions to unlock, and each having 3 ways to potentially use them, you can see the amount of customization gets exponential.  And even more in new game plus when it allows you to unlock another copy of an already used function.Using the functions in the variety of ways will also reward the story loving fanatics.  Each function you discover is linked to one pronounced citizen of Cloudbank, and as you use the functions in combat you'll unlock background information regarding their history.  It's a fun way to learn more about the story and reward players for trying new combinations of function loadouts.While the story of Transistor may seem eerily similar to Bastion the combat game play is quite different.  Arguably Transistor can be played in the same real time hack-n-slash style of Bastion, but in all likelihood you'll be using the strategic pause mode for most battles.  This mode feels like a turn based strategy game.   When combat is paused you are shown a progress bar of action points to spend.  Every movement, every function will use up action points until the bar is full.   This allows you to plan out your attack before committing to the plan.  Once you execute a plan you'll see all your attacks played out in real time.  You'll then need to fight in real time as you wait for the cool down timer on strategic mode.  It really is a good balance of real time and turn based combat.The thing I loved most about Bastion was it's story, soundtrack and art direction, and once again with Transistor they delivered.   A hauntingly desolate city again brought to life by beautiful landscapes and enchanting music you'll be humming along the way with Red.While it may be relatively short it has replay value in new game plus, just to try more function combos.  If you enjoyed Bastion then you'll find Transistor worthy of a play.

content:
9, 2014
												Supergiant has made another innovative game with great art, and this time, with superb gameplay. Unlike their last game, Bastion, Transistor has a much more in-depth combat system that is cool to toy around with. Now for what everyone's waiting for: the story. The story of Transistor is very similar to the one that was in Bastion's. Supergiant brings back many of the things we've loved from Bastion and puts in it Transistor. The game drops you into a world that is being torn apart, and you have to try and fix it. There is a narrator in the game that serves to tell the story about how the world around you was, although he takes a more laid back seat in his role in that instead of narrating every single thing you're doing, here, he'll talk to you as a companion and friend. While the fact that the story between the two games is almost identical, the main difference between the two games is the world you're dropped in, and why the world is being destroyed.You start off in not so much as a world that Supergiant has made, but a city called Cloudbank that is part of that world. Cloudbank has a Tron kind of feel, where it is unsure whether the characters you are seeing are really alive, or just some programs living in a digital world. On the one hand, when they die, their souls or processes go into your Transistor, giving you extra powers. On the other hand, the characters are exactly the same as human characters except for that fact. The game tries really hard to demonstrate this idea that even though every character in the game is some kind of computer program, they still have all behave differently and have flaws like normal humans. Characters end up having tons of personality, except instead of forcing you to learn about them, Transistor does this more subtly by giving you the choice to read about the lore of the world or not.The storytelling in the game has also been improved from Bastion. Instead of the singlular path of find all the cores, find all the shards, then find the last core and the last shard to power up the bastion machine, Transistor's story is a lot less linear and way more subtle. As said before, much of the story lies in the background of the powers you gain, as well as the OVC stations (pretty much the newspaper) that are placed around Cloudbank. Transistor focuses mainly on telling a good story but because of that, it ends a little short. By no means is Bastion a bad story, but it was practically one big fetch quest for 70% of the game, which was good because it made the game longer, but the story was made weaker and the weakness in its gameplay was made much more obvious. If anything, I wish this game was longer but at least the story doesnt feel as forced as Bastion, forcing you to continuously retrieve things to power the bastion. Your playthrough could last anywhere from 4-5 hours on the first playthroughbut there is a new game+ mode called recursion in the game that lets you keep all your abilities and your level as you start the game over again.Other than the story, the gameplay is the most noticeable improvement in Transistor. Instead of dodge rolling and then spamming left or right click, this game relies on 4 active skills that you can add 2 passive skills to each, and 4 passive skills that buff your character. Each and every skill you have can go into any of these categories and its up to you to mix and match each skill to fit your playstle. You use these 4 actives in combat and when you are in a pinch, you can use the pause mechanic which allows you to plan your attack. With these mechanics,Transistor is a much more tactical and interesting game  since you get to carry most, if not all, of your skills into combat with you into a fight. In the end, Transistor has taken many of the things in Bastions, and improved on them. The story has been made less linear, the gameplay has been totally rehauled, and you'll fall in love with the art style, the crumbling world, and the characters all over again.

content:
er 26, 2014
												Transistor is a fantastic game: great music, great visuals, great gameplay, and an interesting story.This one hit all the sweet spots, in my opinion. Good length, too - each play through (and it's very much worth recursing/game+'ing the game once) takes about 10 hours.Now, if you're looking for another Bastion, then you may be disappointed. Most of Transistor's combat takes place in a  turn-based mode, where you plan out your movement/attacks, then execute your plan and watch it play out. You can fight in real time (and some of the challenge trials are actually easier this way), but for the most part you'll end up taking too much damage and/or getting knocked out of your attacks to make it a very useful way to play.Difficulty is great, in that it scales wonderfully. By default, you'll have a fairly easy time killing the Process. However, there are 10 limiters that you can choose, which will make the Process stronger, in exchange for faster leveling up. I can honestly tell you that running with all 10 limiters will make for a very harrowing experience.Again, as I mentioned, you should totally play at least twice - first time around gives a good experience, but the second time around - when both you and the Process are leveled up, and you can start stacking functions for extra-brokeness and fun, is what really makes the game.Final word - this is the only game that I've gone out of my way to get 100% of the achievements.

												I just finished this game, and I'm sad to have to see it end. It was a truly fantastic game, on par if not better in its own way than Bastion. The story interested me and held my attention throughout, especially with the way it tells itself through the narration and environment. The music and art style were absolutely beautiful as I'm sure you will hear many people say. The combat felt fresh to me, easy to get a grip on but nothing I've ever really seen before.The only nitpicks I have with the game are: A) The boss fights are dreadfully easy once you get a hang of the game.B) There is a certain enemy type towards the end of the game that felt really cheap to me (though that may just be because I was worse at the game than I thought).C) I'm not sure how I came under the impression, but I thought "Recursion Mode" (New Game+) would include extra story elements or different dialogue in certain areas. After a bit of research after finishing the game, I discovered it was nearly all enemy layouts and enemy difficulty and such, much to my dismay. Though if you're into the combat, I suppose that's not really a negative.D) My game crashed. Once. In a challenge map. Before it began. After the game saved. No biggy, but something to watch out for.Overall, absolutely amazing game that will stick with me for a while, and may very well become one of my favourite games. I whole-heartedly recommend buying it, especially if you enjoyed Bastion. Even if you didn't, buy it anyways, Supergiant deserves all of your money.10/10 would bang, play, finish, get upset by, reason with myself so I stop getting upset by and then write a review that got way longer than I intended again.

												Hello world!Supergiant comes back with another installment, same narrator (or at least the same actor), world still falling apart, but this time, it's in the future!For Bastion fans, Transistor has all of the flavors of  Bastion, with a whole new story and significantly changed combat elements.Combat this time often time involves the usage of the "Turn()" ability.Turn() is essentially a planning phase where you can plan out your attacks, then when you execute, it happens instantaneously, then you have a recharge time before it can be used again.Being in the non-discript space future, there are a decent amount of programming references embedded into the game.As a programmer, I thought that was kinda cool, because I felt like I had a secret hand shake with the developers saying "Hey, I got that!"Even if you're not a programmer, those minor references don't really effect the story at all, so nothing will be missed by anyone that plays this game.So to break down the pieces, gameplay, I would say is equivalent to the level that Bastion output.Music, dare I say, better than Bastion. The song for the trailer, We All Become was fantastic. Old Friends was great as well.Combat, personally, I liked it. I've heard some friends that preferred Bastion's combat system to Transistor, but I'm definitely a fan of RPGs, and Transistor feels more like an RPG with its system.Story, I'm kind of mixed. Shortly in, it becomes apparent that there are elements of romance. My video game taste palate initially wasn't expected a romance, but grew to accept and even really like where it took the story.All of those elements combined, it makes this game one of my absolute favorites.I would absolutely recommend it.Gotta get that ten outta ten!System.exit(0) || return 0; //Whichever you prefer.

												In Transistor, you play as Red, a famous singer who is targeted by a mysterious group known as the Camerata. Fortunately, you escape, taking with you the mysterious sword-like Transistor - containing the soul of a man you once knew. Above all else, Transistor is a love story. It tells the tale of a woman in love with a city, its people, and maybe even a sword. Set to a fantastic score by Darren Korb (also from Bastion), the world is full of vibrance and culture. Every area reveals more of the city and the culmination of events that led to the formation of the Camerata and the invasion of the Process.Play it if you:+ Enjoyed Bastion+ Enjoy strong narrative and world building+ Like isometric gameplay (a la Diablo and Bastion)

												Bastion was a major case of "came for gameplay, stayed for aesthetics". Transistor is more like "came for aesthetics, stayed for aesthetics". Gameplay is ok, but does not become tedius only because the game itself is rather short. Planning the turn and combining the effects are interesting mechanics, but have little actual depth and are fun only for the 6-7 hours it takes to beat the game once. Which is kind of perfect.Now, the aesthetics are brilliant. A futuristic sci-fi city where programming code is a part of everyday reality, is painted in the most unlikely style of Art Nouveau, and this unexpected combination provides a unique experience. Like in Bastion, sound is very tightly knit to the visual, to an almost synaesthetic effect.The story has two very different layers. The big picture is vague: to the very end we can only guess what the city actually is, can one leave it or not, what is the nature of the forse destroying it, and so on. This, however, is not sloppy worldbuilding, but rather a deliberate refusal to focus on the minutae of the narrative background and keep it blurred to focus on the story of Red, which is told with all the immediacy. A human story of hard work, love, betrayal, retribution and redemption gets through, from the first cue of the man in sword, to the last pictures in the credits.

content:
1, 2015
												Transistor is... interesting. I was sucked in by the number of potential combinations of combat abilities - and then I stuck around for the beautiful artwork and atmosphere of the game.Transistor is an orthogonal view RPG - similar to those of the early 2000s. It's not standard, though: you don't have a party of multiple characters, and you don't have conversations with NPCs (or at least, not as such). Combat occurs in bounded areas, which you can't leave until finishing the combat - but your character can move freely within these. Abilities can be used in real time, or planned out using a "pause" kind of ability (which has to recharge after being used), making the combat more turn based and strategy focused.There are three main things however, which really make the game shine.First is the mystery/detective style story. The game starts with your character right in the middle of things, with very little explanation - and as the player, you spend the game trying figure out what happened and what exactly is going on. I found this to be a great storytelling technique, and very quickly got me hooked. Little snippets of information are "fed" to you through by your narrator companion; you also find various clues as you explore.Another way of finding information is cleverly linked to the second notable thing about this game: the combat abilities.As you progress through the game, (and level), you receive abilities called 'Functions' (a computer programming reference). Each one can be used as an active ability, set as a passive bonus, or used as an upgrade to your active Functions. This means that each new function you gain can have 3 different effects - and there are then an almost limitless number of potential combinations. The best thing about this though, is that you can freely change how you combine your Functions throughout the game. If something's not working for you, change it up. You can use one set-up to be effective against large numbers of weak monsters, and then change again for the boss battles. If you think a particular combination of Functions might be cool, fun - or even just good for a laugh - try it out, and you can always change again later. This encourages improvisation and experimentation, while also removing the pressure of making the right decisions on how to upgrade your character (which sometimes detracts in other games).The Functions also tie in with the game's backstory. Each one is named after a character (including the one you control), and as you use the Function in different ways, more information about this character is available to read. This acts as another incentive to change around your Function combinations by slowly feeding you more of the story.Finally, the whole atmosphere of the game really is something to experience. The character portraits and cutscene artwork are amazing, the way the protagonist hums along to the soundtrack of the game... I'm not sure what else to say - you have to see if for yourself.Only a few complaints:I found the combat to be a bit of a grind as I neared the end of the game (though that may just be me).I also thought everyone's praises of the soundtrack were overrated, and left me disappointed. Ashley Barrett's vocals *are* stunning - but although the the music fits the environment of the game, it's just repetitive and mostly forgettable.If all that leaves you wanting to know more - go play it! Why are you still reading this?However, if that doesn't grab your attention, and you prefer your games to be a bit more standard with an overt story that starts more slowly - this one isn't for you.

er 29, 2014
												Most people say that you need around 6 hours to beat this once.If you explore every bit and wait for every dialogue, play around with the different functions, crank up the difficulty to max whenever possible and only have reasonable luck with the random based challenges 8-10h is more appropriate (listening to the awesome music included).So with actually playing the game it's 10 hours worth of amazing content for the first playthrough. And the second seems to offer some more things to keep you entertained.I didn't find anything that this game does not do really good except for some user interface issues (mostly when installing functions, though you can drag&drop and stuff, it's just a bit strange when you change a whole lot).---------Please be aware though, there is one minor design flaw. In fact this may wipe your progress if you are not careful so please read on IF you want to play on maxed difficulty and change around your playstyle a lot:After reaching the top of the tower DO NOT LEAVE unless you have a foolproof ability kit or turned off all/some limiters. The game saves after a cut-scene and you will have to fight a high tier dog and some minions. YOU DO NOT GET THE OPTION TO CHANGE YOUR BUILD EVEN IF YOU LOAD. You can pretty much always beat anything before even with a sub-par build and a few deaths but this encounter can be devastating with the wrong build. It took me several minutes of optimizing a test build that was not working as intended.---------Probably the only game where I used Tab for other things than minimizing the window. And I used it a lot. Definitely the only game where I didn't do anything else except holding the Tab key at times...Buy this if you have a working Tab key. If not, wait for a discount. Or don't, because it's incredible. Seriously, the only problem people are having with this game is that it is too short. Great games are always too short, or we wouldn't play the bad games anyway...Edit: 2nd playthroughThe design flaw as explained above is here more apparent and it happens more often, though you should have a good setup at this point anyway. being able to have multiples of the same function also makes stuff very interesting. Most encounters are very easy (with the correct kit) but some encounters seem to be randomized so you can have pretty challenging fights, even though I nearly instantly killed anything, I still only had about 20-30% life after most fights. The challenge rooms you get access to are okay (fighting against a last boss kind of type is forgettable though), the randomized fights can be a nightmare and the repeating "only fighting against an increasing number of men" is dumb and very unfair with the wrong abilities. This changes in the later rooms though and I had some pretty fun times going through the last 16 waves, losing my good abilities right at the start and only reaching my standard setup right at the last wave. So far a recursion seems unnecessary, the real meat (plot, style, music) is already inside your bellies, so the only thing left is to play around with the game mechanics. Those are excellent but you should know when to stop before you ruin your experience. See that mode as optional and not as required and you will be fine :)

ber 3, 2015
												Transistor is a top-down, turn-based adventure game that takes place in a utopian society. The gameplay is very different from Bastion; in this game, all attacks are planned beforehand during each turn. This game is beautiful to look at and holds a beautiful story within.Pros:+From the music, to the voice acting, to the writing, to the art, this game is beautifully executed. I like the gameplay, but this is definitely a game you buy for the music, story and artwork.+The romance in this game felt genuine and believable to me.+The gameplay is entertaining; different "functions" (attacks) can be combined in a multitude of combinations, and there are multiple ways to win each battle.+Like Bastion, there is a new game plus mode where you can restart the game at a higher difficulty and continue levelling.+For those who like the battles, there are bonus challenges, similar to Bastion.Cons:-While planning your turn, you can't pan the screen to look at far away enemies. This is a minimal problem, as you can usually see far enough anyways, and you can also simply walk where you want to see and then cancel the move.This game took me ten hours to complete, but my girlfriend completed it in four hours, which I find amazing. I think most people will take at least six if not 7-8 hours.I really loved this game. While they don't have the big budget of a AAA company, Supergiant has managed to craft something that is both more unique and more impressive than most AAA games.

												Transistor combines a beutiful world, a fantastic soundtrack, and satisfying combat to create a great game held back both by an overly vague story and a lack of things to do.  The game isn't long, which isn't too much of a problem, but I left it wanting more, and not simply new game plus.  I wanted more new enemies, more stories, more boss fights.  If you're fine with a shorter experience, then Transistor is a must-buy.  Hell, if you're fine with a game that relies on new game plus to last a long time, then Transistor is still a must-buy.

												Not great but ok. I can't avoid comparing it to Bastion. You have main story, you have storyteller, you have your own place where you can rest (Bastion in Bastion, Backdoor in Transistor). In overall it looks like developers tried to repeat success of Bastion. But the problem is that story is not that great, art is not as detailed as in Bastion, soundtrack is boring and repetitive and whole Backdoor concept is useless. As for Backdoor I hate it the most. In Bastion you could build your own island to receive new stuff and complete trials to receive parts needed to upgrade your weapons. In Transistor you have Backdoor where you can complete trials to unlock new songs from soundtrack to listen in only in Backdoor. And thats all.

												Have you ever thought about playing with art? Well, if you're visiting this game's page, this is your chance to see how it feels like!First of all, this is no simple indie easy money score. You can see that there were hours spent on dedicated work, constructing this piece of art. I can start by telling you what you already know and what makes this game easy on your boring days, but, instead, I'll just skip to what makes it good and different.Imagine yourself playing a Neil Gaiman's graphic novel (storyline and arts), produced by a Blizzard (isometric gods) and Square Enix (turn based combat milestone) partnership. This gets close to the experience. You will never believe how awesome this game's battles are, until you actually play it. So many possibilities... very few enemy types though. And about the graphic/arts... there is so much to say about it. You may see a mix steam punk and futuristic sci-fi on the references. Gorgeous begin to describe... And the soundtrack?! Mesh up old club music with electronic beats and you get really impressive results!This game was born a classic. With so many uncreative work popping up every single day, this game only lacks more world wide publicity to get it amongst the great ones, where it belongs.
